This game is intense, it reminds me of terraria or starbound, (just not as voxeling) You go out and try to find components and food (mainly food) just to stay alive during times of war, it is highly addicting, and replayability is easily achived, i would have more time played but i've been busy with work.  the art style is amazing, its kind of like you are playing a book, theres no voice acting or anything but text but i could care less if there was voice acting.  the combat is mouse clicking like crazy unless you have stealth perk and then you can sneak up on people and assassinate them with a knife in your inventory.  the game gets progressively harder as you play, the days get colder and raids on your base get more intense (if you don't got guns by day 10 your followers will start getting injured)  and damn people having feeling and feelin sorry for killing innocent people or stealing from other people!! makes scavaging hard to do unless you don't give a sh&t about your followers feelings!  MUST HAVE SURVIVAL GAME OF 2015!!!  P.S also sounds like the devs will be adding more even though they say the game is full release, hopfully see some more follower addons or other goodies!
This game is really fun, and challenging, with a decent amount of replay value. The developer needs to come out with a new 'campaign' so we are not always playing the same buildings.

Overall this is a very good game for the artistic representation of the oppression of war, however, as a game it has flaws as well.  Pros:  + The atmosphere is very good. + The personalization of the story to a few people who vary different plays is well-designed. + The 'feel' of the game is very sad and effective for the topic - and I really like the art. + All of this adds up to a strong experience.  Not plusses:  - Like any game of the type, it has to invent some ways making it a 'game', and those aren't always enjoyable - do you have enough food, heat, morale, etc.  - That gaming side tends to take you out of the game a bit learning ways to 'game the system' - how best to do what the game wants more than relating to the situation depicted.  But that last point isn't as bad as it sounds. The game does well mostly at those gameplay elements, despicting issues and other people in the game, and providing options for different playstyles.  It's not a game I really feel warm and fuzzy about returning to, and I don't really look forward to parts like the combat side. But I think it's a great experience worth trying.

'Do you recommend this game?' YES!   This game is great and it may not be your typical 'shoot them up' game and get as much attention as them but it is just great. The way it keeps you anticipated and makes you a nervous wreck is saying something. With other survivors around you and you possibly having to steal or kill them just to get along is alot. You may be thinking I don't care anout other survivors... Thats what I thought but you know, they don't all get angry and pull out machine guns and spray you down. For example I may or may not have battered a woman for no reason other than the fact that my man for some reason randomly ran into the house and got her attention. But she did try to fight me off and when realised she was losing ran to her companion upstairs, (most likely her bf due to she was female and he male) he then came down with her and for a walked around the house together. Then he told her to wait inside and he just went to check outside, I took my chance to finish her off and it made me feel kind off like laughing (hope I'm not a physco) but also sad because before she died she whispered 'please no.' This made it obvious she was just a survivor as she said this in our first encounter, when I broke into the house, so I kind of felt like I was robbing relatives almost or a friend I knew, but in this war ridden town you have to do what you have to do, right?   Obviously since I can say so much about one encounter I've had shows it's a emotional game, that does not meen it's some love fantasy game or any of that crap. It's a serious game with a depressing edge to it. I find the best comparison is real life, you always have happy moments in wars but it's also a very unhappy place and most likely dangerous if you're in the centre of it. It's like stalingrad, destroyed and not much supplies to go around (In WWII obviously.) I feel like I bought this game 5 mins ago and I'm looking at how long I've played it for: 4.2 hrs last two weeks / 4.2 hrs on record. I only just bought this game and I've fell in love with it. If you like the sound of this game please check it out on youtube or other reviews don't just take my word for it. But please give this game a chance because it obviously hasn't got the same publicity as other games but I feel it really, really deserves it. Great game. (My grammar, punctuation and spelling may not be the best but it doesn't matter, right?)

This War of Mine  Pro + Very good concept + Artwork suits with the game quite well + Putting moral decisions into the game without forcing it. Well done.  Con - Repetitive at times - Needs more items and more interaction between characters

I played this game before and I'm still playing but I play in offline mod generally so do not consider my hours on record. Basically this is fantastic game. Seriously you have to think about so many things and you have to figure out how you can make everything good until the end of war while considering ethical and moral things.   For example, once I just killed every people to get their foods and medicines. However then all the players started becoming depressed and that was really hard to control or I tried to play 'nice man' but then I died because I gave all the important things to someone else when they asked. Those children want really much !! Or in the Quite House I did not want to kill those older couple but after 10-15 days when we out of everything I had to kill them.   Basic tips: - Without Marko surviving is really difficult because when you go to scavenge, you have to come back as much as possible. - If you are making your story, for the supermarket choose the soldier section because easily you can have a rifle and also because you save that woman everyone will feel nice. - When you start the game make a metal workshop and then a shovel. - After that make at least one bed immediately and be sure in a while you need to have beds for every person. - Upgrade your metal workshop, oven and workshop as soon as possible.  - Do not give food everyday. I think best way is food per 2 days.  To make this game better: - When someone comes to you and says 'we need this could you give me.' Sometimes you do not have what needed and you have to say no. There should be an option like 'I'm sorry we do not have what you want.' You can use it both way. I mean in truth manner or lie manner. Sometimes even you have you can say ohh sorry we do not have and it makes the players depressed. - Definitely we have to be able to double scavenge because even you have Marko, 15 slots is not enough.

As most other reviews will tell you, This War of Mine (TWOM) offers a gaming experience from a perspective rarely seen in urban warfare environments - that of the civilians. This game charts the progress of a group of mismatched individuals who find themselves trapped within a wartorn city that is under siege by the military trying to wrest control of it back from rebel forces. There is no infrastructure, no power or running water. The city is crumbling, withering on the vine, and the group you control are right in the middle of the rotting heart.  Your survivors begin the game in a relatively large abode they have chosen as their base camp. To call it a home or even a house is laughable - the walls are falling down, there is debris everywhere and the fridge is empty. The primary method of control is point and click - you click on one of your civilians to select them, then click on the action you wish them to take. Actions are context-sensitive - if there is a locked door and you have a lockpick, an appropriate icon can be found next to the door. If there is salvageable debris on the floor, clicking on the hand icon above will direct your civilian to search it. The simplicity of this system helps negate the confusion that can arise from playing the game for the first time and being suddenly presented with dozens of different icons around the abode.  Your survivors spend their days inside their abode, as it is too dangerous to venture outside due to snipers. This is the resource management/crafting section of the game. During this time you can build additional facilities such as stoves, workbenches and rain collectors (assuming you have the resources to build them), you can let your civilians rest/eat, and possibly barter with a passing trader. There are a comprehensive number of different structures that can be built around the place, and many of them can then be upgraded further to either access new items, or make it easier to create existing ones. It is also the part of the game where you will maintain your group's wellbeing, including feeding them, tending to their wounds, and sending them to bed to help them get over their misery.  When night draws in, choices must be made. At this point in the game you can send a single soul out to different locations around the city to scavenge for goodies, be they food, medical supplies, weapons or something else desperately needed by your camp. Once a location is selected, the game becomes a point and click stealth sim, akin to Mark of the Ninja or Deadlight. You have a cone of vision, and other NPCs in the location, if you can't see them, may make themselves known to you by their sound, which will appear as a pulsating red circle.  Night scavenging is a diabolically tense affair. When approaching the door to an unknown property, you will have a vague idea what to expect based on the brief synopsis of the area the game gives beforehand. You look through the keyhole and, seeing nothing of note, you open the door and stalk your way into the lounge. Searching a cupboard you find a few blocks of wood and some vegetables. Suddenly, you see it (or rather, hear it). A pulsing red circle, on the ceiling above you. Someone (or something) is here in the house with you. Do they live here? Are they friendly?  Are they alone?  And so the decisions of TWOM assault you, not through binary text choices or sterile morality wheels, but through pure choice.  Do you leave immediately, unwilling to incur the wrath of the inhabitant but knowing you will return empty handed? Do you try to sneak around the ground floor, searching for what little you can, knowing there may be more upstairs? Do you charge upstairs before whatever it is can prepare itself, and ready your crowbar for a fight? Do you draw your pistol, carefully counting the three bullets you have left?  TWOM is not a game you win. It is a game where you try to stay alive as long as you can, doing whatever is necessary to survive. And as the days drag by and the food supplies dwindle and the cold laps at your fingers and Pavle starts getting sicker and the looters get bolder, you will be called upon to answer the question - are you willing to diminish?  Are you willing to steal medicine from a desperate hospital, or let Pavle die from infection? Are you willing to rob a man and his sick father at gunpoint for the food you traded them two days ago, or let Katia starve for another day? Are you willing to murder a vicar in case he has something you can use?  The presentation of TWOM is well considered, using a pencil-sketch art style with 2.5D environments. The game brilliantly conveys a sense of devastation and disrepair within the locales you investigate with little effort. The macabre atmosphere is enhanced by a haunting, albeit not very varied soundtrack containing reverb-drenched guitars, sombre strings and oscillating, industrial percussion. The gameplay, despite using essentially the same mechanics throughout. manages to achieve two very different, almost schizophrenic styles in the contrast between night and day. Days are quiet, slow, reflective encounters, while nights out scavenging are stressful, deadly and panic driven.  The game is not perfect. Combat can be clunky and confusing affair, although this is possibly part of the game intent, demonstrating that violence should be an absolute last resort. However, this does not prevent the immense frustration that I felt when (for the second time) I sneaked up on an armed guard with my shotgun, only to get TOO close at which point my civilian decided that rather than fire a round of buckshot through the guard's back, he would instead try to melee him to death with the butt of the gun. Needless to say, my game ended there. The roguelike element of TWOM means that you will never become 'good' at combat, although that's probably the point. As mentioned before, the music could do with a few more tracks, and does get repetitive (though this does help contribute to the relentless, monochrome tone of the game overall).  I recommend TWOM on the basis that it has the potential to invoke the same ambivalence of mind that can come from, say, the decisions you make in the Walking Dead series, or Dragon Age, but through gameplay rather than specific story choices.  One last thing to mention. After you have started your first game, two options appear on the title screen - Continue, and Another Try. Not 'New Game'. Another Try.  And who knows? Maybe this time you won't die like a dog for no good reason.  War is Hell.
Really love the game, it was challenging.

'The War is Over.' That's the phrase that pops up when you survive the war, and frankly after playing this game that's all the satisfaction you will ever need.   This game is indie. It's not funny, it's not known for its fighting mechanics, but it sends a message that can be summed up in three words 'war is bad.' But of course we already know that right? 9 out of 10 people you ask will probably say that war is bad. They might say support our troops, let the conflict in the middle east end, or hold a moment of silence as a sign of respect. But talk is cheap, actions are what define a person.   By actions are what define a person I am not suggesting a call to action that every single one of us quit our dayjobs or schooling to go rally and achieve world peace. What I am asking is that you experience a very accurate simulation of what war is truly like, because after this game trust me, you will have a whole new understanding of what war is. Playing this game won't suddenly make you relate to the horrors that the REAL victims of war have seen. But it will make you feel like a human being and if you do it right, you will get some strong emotions in the mix too.  If you do get this game, I suggest you try to play it as realistically as possible and as humanly as possible. What I mean by that is that you keep in your mind that these are real people you are controlling, because eventually there will come a point in the game where you will simply forget that. Everytime your character helps someone, you will feel happy. Everytime you turn away a neighbor asking for help you will feel bad. You will see things in the game that you are powerless to stop. Your morals will be questioned all the way until you either survive or perish. Will you steal from an elderly couple? Will you stand up from those who are being abused even if it means putting yourself in danger? Will you barter with the very people who are responsible for ♥♥♥♥♥♥, looting, and taking advantage of ordinary citizens like you? You won't know who you really are until you play this game, until you realize that the game is sad for a reason, until you realize that all of the things that happen in this game could and have happened to other people in real life.  You know war is bad. Now experience it for yourself.  TL:DR I was feeling inspired and emotional. War is bad. Get this game if you have a heart and want to learn at the same time that you have some fun. :)

It took me 3 tries and 18 hours to reach the end of the war with the easiest settings. Once I got the hang of it I didn't find it to be too hard, although since I did have it on settings that were about as easy as it can get so I could learn the game that's really no surprise. It's a really great game, but I probably won't be playing much more. If you're considering buying it, keep in mind that it isn't a game that you'll be throwing countless hours into; you'll play it for a few, and it'll be fun for those few, but after that you'll of had your fill.  I really enjoyed the 18 hours that I've played so far, however I'm not sure how much more I will be playing. While having the honor of saying I beat it on the hardest difficulty would be nice, this game doesn't have a whole lot of replayability. If I did go for another playthrough, I don't think it would be near as enjoyable. I would be going to the same buildings as before, getting the same supplies as before, and making the same things as before, meanwhile dealing with the same problems such as lack of food, medical supplies, supplies in general, and obstacles in the way of gathering supplies. This game is very enjoyable once, but I really have no interest in going again.  Another problem I had besides there being little replay interest was that often I found myself just sitting there bored on many days while I waited for someone to finish sleeping, just to have them go and craft something that will take them 3 hours, meaning more sitting and waiting. I really wish there was some way to fast forward through this other than the end day button, which is really only useful when you have done everything that you wanted to do for that day.   Those are my biggest issues with the game. That being said, I still recommend this game. Other than those, the game is very enjoyable. There's a lot to think about when you play, and messing one thing up could completely screw you over. I'd say overall, the biggest part of this game is resource and moral management, so if you enjoy management games then chances are you would enjoy this one as well. You constantly have to make choices such as do you take more wood or more food? Do you make a better stove or a better heater? Do you give a homeless man some food in the hopes of getting something valuable or play it safe and trade with someone rather than risk not getting anything in return for the food you donated? Do you steal from an elderly couple and doom them to death along with make the characters depressed or do you risk a character's life by stealing from an armed group that's hoarding supplies? Every decision can make an impact, which is important to keep in mind.   Despite there not being a whole lot of replayability for me and times when you just have to sit and wait, overall there is a lot to the game and I recommend it to anyone who thinks they would enjoy it.

The best survivor / war sim I've had the pelasure of playing in a very long time. This game can be extreamly hard and emotional.   My take away lessons for newbies: Don't get attached to your characters, take small steps when exploring new sites, don't get greedy, don't go on a 'revange missions' if you lose a member of your team, sneak in and out of each sites (snipers can be leathal), make sure you take care of them wounds and sickness ASAP, plan ahead for the winter: fortify your home base, build a vaggie garden and traps for food, make as much stuff as you can to trade later on (You will need it). Use the right character for the right action/mission.  The possibilities are endless, the replayability of the game is more than exellent. (Random maps, items, encounters, game lenght... AWESOME)  I love the dark, pencil-style graphic, 2 mode play system (day/night).. Oh and check out ALL the stations on the radio... Some cool tunes hidden in there!  Overall I give this title a 10/10 for story/concept, 9/10 for interface/gameplay (had issues with the combat system)  Personal notes: Combat/defence interface could be improved and the fact that I was still getting raided over and over even after i upgraded the reinforced security door and patched all the holes was kind frustrating, specilally with 2 shotguns and a pistol in my inventory.   Highly recommended.. I fear I will waste many more hours on this title.  Thanks for making this game!

One night, I decided to go scavenging at a supermarket, because all four of us in my group were starving, nearly to death. While I did find food, in good quantity, I also found a soldier and a woman behind a door in the entryway. I didn't want to intrude, I've been shot at before, and nearly shot to death, and I sure as hell didn't want to die, considering a knife isn't much help in a gun fight. I overheard the soldier asking the woman if she needed anything. She responded by saying that she needed food, like everyone else. He said that he could help her, if she 'did a favor' for him. She said, 'No way!' I couldn't see what happened next, but based on the sound effects, and small bits of dialouge, I have concluded that he proceeded to assault her, and eventually put a bullet through her brain.  The next day, I went scavenging there again, as there were a ton of components and various electronic parts I could get. There wasn't a soldier and a woman, but a different woman in the entryway of the supermarket. She asked me, 'did you hear about what happened here? That poor woman... Someone could have saved her.'  I could have saved her.
One of the best games i have ever played. Excellent moral choices, depressing atmosphere and great setting makes this game not only special but also very powerful!

Then Pavle died after getting caught stealing. The girl, Katia, who was sad about Pavle stealing food became uber depressed because he died and was going to kill herself. Bruno talked Katia out of suicide and let her sleep for a few days while he went out scavenging. A women named Emilia had shown up at their door asking if she could stay there. They took her into their home. Emilia went out scavenging that night and never returned after getting shot to death. Kalia who was super depressed said 'I'll never forgive her killers!' and went to fight them the next night and killed everyone asociated with her death. Bruno became scared of her and started drinking what he booze he could find. Bruno slept off his hangover and went out to trade for some more supplies, but was murdered after a misunderstanding. Katia, very injured from the people she had killed was now alone and bed-ridden to heal her wounds. That night the house was robbed, and Katia was murdered. The survivors of that household are now all dead. Game is 10/10 depressing would buy and would recommend

This game was an emotional rollercoaster. Trying to survive the world, from the winter, to the soldiers, to the lack of food, and everything else made the end a relief, but the decisions in between to keep people alive or not was heartbreaking. A superb alternative, chilling, realistic, dark perspective on war. To quote the developer, War is not heroic, War is hell. This game fully explores that fact. 10/10 would recommend, 11/10 would cry, 12/10 would pray for absolution for your sins.

This is a hard game, both in terms of gameplay and in how it affects you. You become attached to these people and are desperate to make the right choices but you will make mistakes. People will suffer and they will die. Others will survive but may not have happy lives afterward. And some will manage to find peace in the end and go on. This is a game everyone should play and experience.

This game is amazing. It took me a few play throughs to really be hit by it but this last one shook me. Let me explain my story without spoiling anything.   The first several days were going well. The three of us, Arica, Roman, and Bruno, were scavenging supplies, defending, and resting while upgrading the base. We were lucky enough to have friendly neighbors that would bring over supplies. When tragedy struck them, we were more than happy to help.   After sometime, a lonely man, Marko, came to our home begging to join us. Since our home was well established, we welcomed him in. Right about the time our newest member was starting to fit it, tragedy struck and Marko was ripped from our lives. At the same time, supplies were getting harder to come by and we resulted to actions we never thought possible. While it shook us, we were still surviving.   Everything was going fairly well until winter came. The first couple of days were fine, but how were we to know the toll winter would have on us? We even relucantly welcomed, Cveta, to our band of survivors. Out of desperation, supplies were being gathered at whatever cost. This is how we lost Roman. We didn't even have time to mourn Roman when Arica failed to come back.  What was once a solid group of survivors was boiled down to two, Bruno and Cveta. Unfortunately, do to the weather, recent tragedies, and lack of supplies, Cveta became gravely ill. Our neighbors were also struck by tragedy but we were unable to offer them assistance this time. Desperately, we hung to the radio listening for when the winter would end and possibly even the war. Nothing useful was ever heard.   For days, the cycle continued. No news on the war or winter, Cveta crept closer to death, while Bruno tried desperately to find supplies that were only to be stolen the next night. We even traded away all of our valuables to limp on another day. What's the point of having a gun with no bullets? How long could we go on like this? How have we even survived the last few days in this death cycle?   Finally, finally, a reprieve; winter has ended. Bruno had found some medicine and was slowly nursing Cveta back from near death. We were going to make it! All that was needed was for this war to end. It has been so long, how can it possibly continue? Haven't enough died? What was gained? Still, the radio mocked us by providing no useful information.  This hit Bruno hardest of all, he became paralyzed by depression. To the point that Cveta, while still seriously ill, went out for supplies just to keep us going. What other choice did she have? We were still sick, wounded and slowly starving to death.   Cveta came home late, her injuries made the scavenging very challenging and lengthy. Overall, the haul was ok, but we still needed so much. Out of all the times I thought we wouldn't make it, this day was the start of a new hope that was squashed before it began. Bruno was gone. The brutality of this hell was too much for Bruno and he gave into the thoughts we tried desperately to suppress. Cveta was devastated. Not only had she risked everything so we could survive, but her sickness had worsened. Reluctantly, Cveta stayed home for the night and never woke up in the morning.

Well i will start with: Buy the game or you will miss a masterpiece.  This game is one of the best i have played and to be honest i only have found one minor bug that you can fix with getting out of your game and get back in. Or you ignore it and continue with a night and what until the next day. That is up to you. What is the bug? The buttons disapear. Its rare but it happened.  Now to the main game. This game is new to most apocalypse survival games. No Zombies. Only Humans. And it all depends on you how it ends. Similar to my 'Long live the queen' it is roguelike. You start with nothing and have to search for everything. The first item you get is a shovel but even that is a thing you have to craft. And after that everything is on you. You search through the different buildings, trade with a trader that comes to you sometimes. Sometimes people from other shelters ask for your help or even give you things.  One time when i played the game i went into a school building and read in the description that these people probably wont be as friendly as they look like. I went in with the thought of bandits and started to kill the first guy. After he was dead another came in and i murdered him directly. But then other people came and instead of attacking me they ran away and tried to look for help. In this case it wasnt them. It was me. I was the bandit that just brutaly murdered two innocent people. The game made me feel so bad about it that i didnt play for a little while.  It is your decision how this game ends. You can be stealthy or run in gunz blazin. But keep in mind that not everyone that carries a weapon or even a firearm is bad. Sometimes they just look for help or do not even want to hurt you and look for some stuff just as well as you do.
yes, good game, i hope in future update
I don't know what to say. It's super awesome!

Can't ... stop ... playing...  i absolute love this game. It's an absolute masterpiece! The only thing why maybe people give a bad review is that the game is absolute depressiv. You feel the absolute depression all over. ever time you run out of food and have to steal from people, or have to shoot a helpless guy to get on his stuff. Everytime one of your survivors die, or they psychological break-down, you feel with them.  In my opinion, exactly this deep should a good game be, it should people give the feeling about the game. If you to soft, go play a shooter and hurt senseless running zombies. for all others an absolute must have!

When bought on Steamsales this game is highly worth it.  It's a fresh take on base-building and survivalism, as well as the moral complexity of war and the choices people have to make.  Critique:  Gets repetative after second play Desperatly needs random/unscripted events, one you've seen/explored something prepare to see it again and again and again. Desperatly needs base attacks etc., combat is nice but it gets to easy once you realize how insane stealthkills are Needs more items and build-options, 'It's a desperate war: Hardly any resources, food or clean water... LETS BUILD A GODAMN DISTILLERY DJYEEAAAAAH'. Water is literally the most important commodity in war, with clean water paramount since dirreah/stomach sickness can be lethal when nutrition is scarce. Yet most water is spent on alcohol or godamn plants; Why do plants need filtered water?! Needs boobytraps etc.  Still, overall I am pleased and I'm usually a critical, cynical, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

What a brilliantly original game -- Such a simple concept executed perfectly; You find yourself instantly engaging and empathising with the players as you struggle night by night trying to maintain their survival Would definitely recommend to any fan of the survival/war genre

If you were into war games like me, then this game will completely change the view you have on war  When i first entered someone else's home, my mindset was 'LETS GOOO KILL SOME PEEPS'  when i looked through the door i saw a person armed with a gun on guard i took cover then opened fire on the guard  after four shots he finally died i look through the door behind him and saw i dying old man who was also sick i realise that the guard was simply trying to protect him out of mercy i decided to kill him in his sleep  This is when i realised i had just killed an innocent old man who had fallen victim to a horrible war, just to survive another day  This game hit me right in the feels 10/10 good job game devs, you actually made me sad for killing someone
THIS GAME is good i think

This War of Mine is a lesson in human greed, war, survival, needs and futility. All of those things combined get you to make decisions in this game that are painful to make. I have played through 4 or 5 games now (29 hours in game at the time of this writing) and each has played out differently. I survived only one game so far (you win by surviving the war) while losing several people over the course of the other games.   I have only found/fixed/crafted a gun once in those games I have played. So they are kind of rare, but luck plays a role here, too. Food is expensive and meds are very expensive. Expect to trade nearly half your belongings for a couple bandages or pills. But that's probably how it would be in war. Necessities would be expensive.   It is depressing but addicting, Without spoilering it for you, play it. You wil get depressed and frustrated but that's the reason to play again. I would love to see Steam Workshop support for mods. I would definately buy an expansion, too.  Buy it. You'll be sorry.

This game should have been GOTY. I'm not kidding. This game made me feel, and it's one of the best games I've ever played. You play as a collection of civilians trapped in a city torn apart by war. This is the only game I've ever played that has you controlling civilians. Your goal is to lead these people to safety, by staying alive in a city full of bandits and cruelty. Everybody has a unique story to tell, but you can only hear it by keeping them alive. This is no easy task. This city is full of bandits and profiteers, who will not hesitate to kill and rob to save their own skins. But for every two villains, there is a hero. That person across the street might save your life by giving you food, out of the kindness of their hearts. The man who begged you to help save his friend might give you medicine or some valuable trading commodities. But are you willing to risk it? Will you risk your life by attacking a fully armed soldier carrying an assault rifle, just to save a stranger from a fate worse than death? Will you give food to the starving man, knowing full well that you will get nothing in return? Or will you take a different path? Are you desperate enough to rob an elderly couple just for a can of tuna? Will you steal from those kids on the verge of death, in order to get the medicine that you need? You will face these kinds of questions every day. You don't know when this war will end. You don't know if these people are good or bad. You just want to survive another day. But the question remains, how far will you go to survive?  The Good: +Great art style +Thought provoking and emotional choices +Gameplay centered on scavenging and stealth +Pulse pounding combat  The Bad: -Can be very difficult for some people -While combat is intense, it's still basic  Final Score: 9/10  I was VERY tempted to give a full 10/10, but the combat could use some improvement. I sincerely hope that there will be a sequel!

Whatever was missing in the previous survival games, This War of Mine is on its way of claiming to be the ultimate in its field!  The graphics, sound design, crafting systems, combat mechanics are all optimized and are an extension of each other in every direction you could possibly connect the nodes. I haven't had the experience of playing so much on a single game time and time again since 2004's Half-Life 2 and Far Cry.  Naturally feeling the torn down environment and the grimy atmosphere, TwoM puts you in the skin of the civilians instead of the usual soldier and teaches you how to survive as well as displaying some of the harsh realities that are faced every day in war. I'm sure no close at all to know just how difficult it is, but This War Of Mine brought me as close to that feeling as possible and that's an experience I will never forget.  All your decision matter which is the ultimate climax of all its elements and is also the drive that keeps you going in the game for houres on end.  The developers earn the amazing review for their hard work and quite frankly I haven't seen an indie game as good as this one in 2014. Please buy the game and support them for future games, as that's all I want to see from them!  My score is a first and well-deserved 10/10 in the GamingReviews series and hopefully I'll be able to review even more, equally amazing games from 11 Bit Studios in the future. What a game! At first I tought it was just another indie-survival-something-something but This War of Mine is one of those games that change the way you see things and it begins just as everything else: War never changes.  You and 2 of your friends must endure a siege as unprepared civilians. Yeah... That Sarayevo siege but they'll never call it on game. You'll explore the city looking for stuff, trying to trade and survive and as winter comes, you'll see the real face of most of the human kind: Looters and criminals will kill people that used to trade with you and you'll remember their names.  Sometimes you won't make it as some events in-game are random but other times you'll survive and wish that war never started at first place.  High replayability rate and aparently, the Devs like developping, so the game is alwayes looking better and better.  It was the best purshase I made last sale and I wish I knew this game before. It's a solid 9.5/10

Even on easy it's quite difficult to make it to the end, you'll face some tough choices. The atmosphere is very grim, it carries a deep undertone. Many of the things you encounter are quite depressing, losing one of your characters, having to steal from (and possibly kill) elderly people, reading about children who have died. A confronting reality check showing you that a post apocalyptic setting is not about being the hero, it's about scraping by trying not to die and hoping for the best.  The gameplay: it's very strategic and reading a 'what to build first' post is nothing to be ashamed of. Combat is very difficult and risky (emphasizing that it should be avoided). You'll probably want to have a piece of paper on hand to write down the amount of resources you need before you go out scavenging to avoid missing that one part you need to upgrade your hideout.  The one thing that bugged me about the game was that you can only have one save at a time, not that I'd want to quicksave all the time, I just want to be able to have separate stories going at the same time without having to rename the save file in the game folders.

Never have I ever felt as depressed as this game has made me.  Odd sentece to start this review, I know, however, allow me explain why this still a positive review.  This War of Mine is an amazing execution of the roguelike genre that uses that overused theme of War that most of our games now a days seem to have grown fond of using, however, they delve into things we generally do not think about, the civilian aspect of war. What happens to those who are not soldiers.   This game is one of the few games that have made me stop for a second and consider the moral implications of my actions. Do I starve to death, or do I kill to survive? That is a question that made me stop playing the first time I played this game.   It doesn't demonizes the enemy, hell, it humanizes it. They are other scavengers, survivors trying to hold out in the worst time of their live. It reminds us that war is more than just 'Terrorists and Counter-terrorists', it's those caught inbetween the fight, unable to escape.  It's one of the best thought, best designed games I've seen in a while, with a sound track that will get into you.  This is a game you simply MUST play at least once in your life.

The best game I've played in years! I like this game mostly because you have to think and plan your EVERY move.   Also, I like that there is no 'save/reload' option - when you screw up, people die and there is no way to ressurect them - when 'my' Roman got shot by a sniper and died got really upset. I've got the message 'the war is over' two days later... I've cried! Such a piontless death...   The only thing I don't like is lack of some kind of tutorial or info on the combat system. I had to watch a movie on youtube to figue it out - turns out that killing bad guys (like deserters) is not so difficult after all.
After 2 hours playing, I needed a hot shower, a warm meal and a walk in the sunshine.  10/10 would get depressed again
I like this game alot.

I could play this game forever. I mean, really this is the first game I've ever put so much effort into with such little time. Do what I did and just DIVE into this game reading no WIKI, not watching any gameplay videos, nothing. Complete and utter sink or swim experience, and trust me you'll sink. But it's not the kind of defeat that has you frustrated that makes you want to quit this game.  No.  It's the kind of frustration the festers when you know you made a mistake. I shouldn't have robbed those people, because my survivor is broken and now I can't go out and scavenge for food. I shouldn't have tried to take on those armed thugs because now someone has died. I should have boarded up my house sooner because I thought I could push my greed and make some animal traps and survive the night with just an axe.  That's the kind of frustration that we love. That lingering sense of victory behind the shroud of misfortune that this game keeps pulling you into.  You've read all the reviews before you, you know it's features. You know about the sense of immersion that game has, so how about replayability?  TWOM's replayability is limited ONLY by your imagination. That's right. Play the game after you have danced with your 25 raw food, your armory of 10 Assault Rifles and 8 Shotguns and make it harder for yourself. Challenge yourself: 'Can I beat this game without killing a SINGLE person?' Then you have something refreshing. Can you defeat winter... with no furnace? 'But that's impossible!' Shh-... It is possible, once you pick apart this game and find that it's real gem is you.  This game brings out all your colors. Your mechanical decision making-side that rushes animal traps so you can float raw food. The emotional shade that tugs on your heart when you kill Emil leaving the widow there to cry. All of that and more.  10 out of holy-crap-sticks-made-of-gold 10.  A game I will never forget, and neither will you.

This is one of my favorite games, not just because it has an interesting concept and I enjoy the gameplay but because it got be interested in other things beyond the game, such as the Siege of Sarajevo. Honestly before playing this I never gave much thought into what it was like to live in a country in the middle of a war. As an American I can feel safe when my country fights because the wars are thousands of miles from me. I'm glad that this game gave me a tiniest of glimpse of what it's like to be in those wars but not as a soldier.   While after my third or fourth play through I started seeing it more as a game there are still moments when I'm jolted out of the gamer mindset. Like when after running past several times I stopped and read the note in the hospital and found that almost all of the patients in the children's ward had died. It was a jaring moment and I felt a real wave of guilt that I hadn't brought any medicine for the doctors.  I treasure games that don't shine war in a light of pure glory, where the player character can triaumph over everything because that's not what war is.

What can I say about this game that has not already be said?  This game has so much going for it. Brilliant game design and stunning graphics. Not to mention the underlying message that the game leaves, and that is 'there is not glory in war'.  Definitely give this game a whirl.

Simple yet Incredibly immersive. Combat is lack luster, but if you want a twitchy auto aim simulator with 3 second thumb sucking hp renewal this isn't it. There is no scripted cut scenes, no press x to not die events. You are completely responsible for every action, and by every action I mean every action. Each stranger could kill you, trade, or just let you pass. It is up to you to decide how to act. From every meal. Every Bandage. Every scrap of wood. Simply precious.  By far the one of the most depresing dishearting games out there. And I love it. It teaches you not to take for granted.   Did I have more entertainment and emotional experience with this game, compared to a trip to the movies? You better belive it. Simply a must have game.

POSTED: 12 APRIL The War of 1812 was a military conflict that lasted from June 18, 1812 to February 18, 1815, fought by the United States of America against Great Britain, its North American colonies, and its North American Indian allies. Historians in the United States and Canada see it as a war in its own right, but Europeans sometimes see it as a minor theatre of the Napoleonic Wars, as it was caused by issues related to that war (especially the Continental System). By the war's end in early 1815 the key issues had been resolved and peace came with no boundary changes.  The United States declared war for several reasons, including trade restrictions brought about by the British war with France, the impressment of as many as 10,000 American merchant sailors into the Royal Navy,[5] British support for Native American tribes fighting American settlers on the frontier, outrage over insults to national honor during the Chesapeake–Leopard Affair, and possible American interest in annexing British territory.[6] The primary British war goal was to defend their North American colonies, although they also hoped to set up a neutral Indian buffer state in the Midwest.  The war was fought in three theatres. First, at sea, warships and privateers of each side attacked the other's merchant ships, while the British blockaded the Atlantic coast of the United States and mounted large raids in the later stages of the war. Second, land and naval battles were fought on the U.S.–Canadian frontier. Third, large-scale battles were fought in the Southern United States and Gulf Coast. At the end of the war, both sides signed and ratified the Treaty of Ghent and, in accordance with the treaty, returned occupied land, prisoners of war and captured ships (though neither side returned the other's warships due to frequent re-commissioning upon capture) to its pre-war owner and resumed friendly trade relations without restriction.  With the majority of its land and naval forces tied down in Europe fighting the Napoleonic Wars, the British used a predominantly defensive strategy in the Provinces of Upper and Lower Canada. Early victories over poorly-led U.S. armies, such as in the Battle of Queenston Heights, demonstrated that the conquest of the Canadas would prove more difficult than anticipated. Despite this, the U.S. was able to inflict serious defeats on Britain's Native American allies, ending the prospect of an Indian confederacy and an independent Native American state in the Midwest under British sponsorship. U.S. forces were also able to make several gains and score victories on the Canadian frontier; taking control of Lake Erie in 1813, seizing western parts of Upper Canada. However, a large-scale U.S. attempt to capture Montreal was repulsed in November 1813. Despite the major U.S. victory at Chippawa on July 5, 1814, serious U.S. attempts to fully conquer Upper Canada were ultimately abandoned following the bloody Battle of Lundy's Lane on July 25, 1814. The U.S. then fell back roughly 30 km (19 mi) from Lundy's Lane to Fort Erie, where they withstood a siege for several months. The British eventually withdrew, but as winter set in, the Americans demolished the fort and fell back across the Niagara.  In April 1814, with the defeat of Napoleon, the British adopted a more aggressive strategy, sending larger invasion armies and tightening their naval blockade. However, with the end of the Napoleonic Wars in Europe, both governments were eager for a return to normality and peace negotiations began in Ghent in August 1814. In the Deep South, General Andrew Jackson destroyed the military strength of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend. In September 1814, the British won the Battle of Hampden, allowing them to occupy eastern Maine, and the British victory at the Battle of Bladensburg in August 1814 allowed them to capture and burn Washington, D.C. They were repulsed, however, in an attempt to take Baltimore and Fort Bowyer, and during their assault at Fayal. An American victory in September 1814 at the Battle of Plattsburgh repulsed the British invasions of New York, which, along with pressure from merchants on the British government, prompted British diplomats to drop their demands at Ghent for an independent native buffer state and territorial claims that London previously sought. Given that it took six weeks for ships to cross the Atlantic, news of the peace treaty did not arrive before the British suffered a major defeat at New Orleans in January 1815.[7]  In the United States, late victories over invading British armies at the battles of Plattsburg, Baltimore (inspiring the United States national anthem, 'The Star-Spangled Banner') and New Orleans produced a sense of euphoria over a 'second war of independence' against Britain.[8][9] The war ended on a high note for Americans, winning the final engagements of the war and bringing an 'Era of Good Feelings' in which partisan animosity nearly vanished in the face of strengthened American nationalism. The war was also a major turning point in the development of the U.S. military. The poor performance of several U.S. militia units, particularly during the 1812–13 invasions of Canada and the 1814 defence of Washington, convinced the U.S. government of the need to move away from its Revolutionary-era reliance on militia and focus on creating a more professional regular force. Spain was involved in fighting in Florida but was not an official belligerent; some Spanish forces fought alongside the British during the Occupation of Pensacola. The U.S. took permanent ownership of Spain's Mobile District.  In Upper and Lower Canada, British and local Canadian militia victories over invading U.S. armies became iconic and promoted the development of a distinct Canadian identity, which included strong loyalty to Britain. Today, particularly in Ontario, memory of the war retains its significance, because the defeat of the invasions ensured that the Canadas would remain part of the British Empire, rather than be annexed by the United States. In Canada, numerous ceremonies took place in 2012 to commemorate the war, offer historical lessons and celebrate 200 years of peace across the border.[10] The conflict has not been commemorated on nearly the same level in the modern-day United States, though it is still taught as an important part of early American history,[11] and Dolley Madison's and Andrew Jackson's respective roles in the war are especially emphasized.[12][13] The war is scarcely remembered in Britain, being heavily overshadowed by the much larger Napoleonic Wars occurring in Europe.

Introduction: ========= This War of Mine definitely delivers!  A game where rather than playing as someone on either side of the war (the military or the rebels), you play as a simple group of survivors trying to survive. A fun, difficult at times, new experience on life during the war. Each character has a unique story, which fits well within the game, and if you survive long enough to make it to the end of the war, you get to find out what happens to each character... But is it positive?  Brief Review: ========== I have made two runs of the game, and made it through both.  Pros: ------- -Difficulty Increases; Survivor group dependent. -Originality; Each playthrough is slightly different. (Locations change, Scenarios change, Seasons change) -Melee Combat; Number generated, more likely to win if your character is well fed and content -Graphics; Simple, gritty, and beautiful -Resonably priced  Cons: ------- -Easy base raids; You will rarely lose a raid with guns for each of your survivors and 10+ ammo -Scavenge Combat; If your scavenger is fully equipped, you are pretty much unstoppable -Sneaking; Sometimes you will be found even though you're making no noise whatsoever.  Thoroughly enjoyed This War of Mine, there is so much potential to replay! Change character group, try different locations for scavenging, and survive many, many a war.  Rating: 8/10    In Depth Review: ============= After playing the game through a second time, I can safely say I have grown more in love with the game.  My first playthrough the war last a very long time. My base become fully secure, I had 5 survivors, and 10 days before the war ended, I had enough medicine, bandages, food, weapons, and armour that my survivors were well fed and content. We never lost raids, and no one could oppose me while scavenging.  My second playthrough the war was very short, lasting half the time of my first playthrough. However, this playthrough had me getting very angry every night. The war started in winter, for almost half of the war, everyone was sick and wounded, and there was very little I could do about it. I could never gather enough resources. The raids started very early, and got very aggressive even earlier, that is what frustrated me the most. Just as I was finally getting a nice stockpile of resources, they would disappear. However, the difficulty increase was refreshing and unexpected and made me strive to beat the game!  Both playthroughs had me in different bases, different seasons and some different starting locations. This was perfect, as it created originality in a sense. First I had to replan my base, as this one was completely new to me. The starting locations were different but familiar. However, even though they were familiar, they had changed ever so slightly. Instead of starting on the left side of a location, I started on the right side of some of them. Scenarios changed, I went to the supermarket and my first playthrough was the 'drunken military officer' scenario, the second was a 'band of thugs'. This through me off, as I only expected one scenario, so I set up for that particular scenario, however I had to retreat and be left with a very unproductive night of scavenging.  On my first play through I didn't really need the alcohol distiller, so I didn't bother seeing what it did and learning what I needed for it. However, on my second play through, making pure alcohol to make bandages and herbal meds, really was a must.  I will update this section with each playthrough, rewriting things that need rewriting and updating new things.

This War of Mine is very realistic. It shows the probability of what would happen if a war broke out IRL, but if a war did break out in IRL, it'd probably be a nuclear war and everyone dies because that's how stupid people are. ANYWAYS.  TWoM is a very fun game, showing how 3 people band togeather and survive or die. Survive long enough, you will meet other survivors on the way, and get a bigger team. The bigger, the harder. Pavle, Katia, and Bruno survived...well, not very long. On day 1, Bruno was already sick, but we found enough supplies in our shelter to make a bed for Bruno to sleep on. We also made a radio, so we could hear what is going on, what ♥♥♥♥ is going down. It seemed to be the Rebels lost a valuable memmber. The weather would be warm, not very rainy for the next few days. I found a nice, good radio station that happened to play classical music, which was lovely with all the shelling and shooting in the background.  Night 1, Pavle went to go scavange, while Katia stood guard and Bruno slept to get better. Pavle found some usefull things, where he went. He found food, weapon parts, components, electronics, wood, etc. The building Pavle went to, well, it was vacant. No one lived there, so it was easy. The only thing that freaked Pavle out was the rats, which he thought were people walking around.  Day 2, the night seemed calm. Bruno seemed to get better, and Pavle got back with the resources. The three began to build a stove, in which they could cook better foods. They also made a metal workshop for better weapons. They did not have enough for any weapons, or enough for lockpicks. They did make a crowbar, and ventured further into the shelter, finding more items, making the workshop able to upgrade. They also made one more bed for Pavle to sleep, Bruno to stand guard, and Katia to go scavanging. Katia and Pavle went to go scavanging on different nights, finding foods, and resources, but no medication. This seemed to be going on for the next few days.  Day 3, not very exiting, some people to sell things.  Day 4, more news on the radio. More classical music.  Day 5, not very exiting.  Day 6, first robbery. We lost some food, even though we were very low on it.  Day 7, A man arrived to tell Katia about an aid drop. All the rebels took alot of it, but there were some in the no-mans land, the man said it was risky, but Katia went anyways, coming back with some food, water, and other resources, but she came back with some more wounds.  Day 8, not very exiting Night 8, Pavle went to Sniper Junction, where he found good loot and saved a man's baby.  Day 9, not very exiting, more robberies, no-one went scavanging due to sickness and injuries.  Day 10, not very exiting.  Day 11, a women showed up and asked to join, and she was very helpfull because she went scavenging the next few nights.  Day 12, More robberies, everyone was injured but the new girl due to scavanging.  Day 13, The New girl died while scavanging.  Day 14, Pavle died from hunger and his injuries, Katia died from severe injures, leaving Bruno with severe injuries, sickness, and his heart broken, fearing for his life.  Day 15...Bruno couldn't take it anymore, and commited suicide.  ***  Katia never found her parents, and when the war was over, her parents went to Katia's grave to mourn for her.  The New Girl(I forget her name)'s parents never showed up, maybe they died.  Pavle's family died during the war.  Bruno's family had mourned for Bruno, but never showed up at his grave, possibly due to the fact the town was just to sad to come back.  Bruno, Pavle, and Katia survived for 15 days total, but they all died as one, meeting each other in the after world, whatever the hell it is.  OVERALL, I seriously enjoyed this game, and nearly brought tears to my ♥♥♥♥in' eyes. I left some details out, mainly because I forgot about them. Katia did some bad things, Pavle did some good things, Bruno helped in every way possible, but didn't go out scavanging.  All in all, I rate this game a ♥♥♥♥in' 9.3/10, it's a very, VERY good game. It was thought and planned out very well, and I ♥♥♥♥in' loved it. Get it now, before the daily deal ends.

While not the flashiest game around, and deceptively simple with its side action scrolling display, This War of Mine is a game that can be both riveting and engrossing.  This isn't a game for those looking for tons of action or a shoot em up. This is a thoughtful game of resource management mixed with sneaking around while on scavenging missions.  You start with anywhere from 1 to 4 characters (randomly generated initially) and your goal is to survive the war. The length of the war is random (25-45 days), and there are numerous randomly generated events to make every survival experience somewhat different.  Some of the random events include illness, attacks by night time raiders, the onset of winter (and extreme cold), and snowstorms and combat making some areas inaccessible. Aside from this the locations you visit have more than one version. You might enter an area that is free of hostile forces. On another playthrough they can be filled with soldiers, rebels or thugs. The locations are also not all available at the start of the game but are instead unveiled throughout the game over time.  Throughout the game you are confronted with moral decisions. Do you help someone or not? Everytime you help someone requires a sacrifice that can cost you in the short term either in terms of time, resources, or risk of injury and potentially death. However, turning away all requests for help can lead to negative consequences on morale. And if someone wants to join you do you value the extra pair of hands more than having another mouth to feed?  Similarly, you'll be presented with opportunities to make hard choices on your scavenging runs. Do you take advantage of the weak? Do you kill innocents? Do you confront those doing wrong or let it happen?  Adding to replayability the resources immediately available to you are also randomly generated. On one play through you'll find you have more than enough wood or parts, on another you'll struggle to find electrical components, weapons or food at your starting location. As the game continues you'll find you never have everything you want or need which forces you to prioritize what you want to build and when.  On top of this your scavenging runs are further constrained by a fixed amount of backpack space. Depending on the character doing the scavenging the amount of space can range from 8 spaces to 17 spaces (1 character), with most having around 10 to 12 spaces.  Similarly, the status of your starting characters are slightly randomized. Sometimes they can start as ill or wounded (slowing you down and forcing you to manage your people more carefully as well as consuming important items like medical supplies).  This is a very good game that will appeal to most but not all. It has solid replayability and multiple ways to win.  One warning, this is a somewhat unforgiving game with a steep learning curve.  There is no 'save' option other than a daily autosave (in case of a crash) which is automatically updated upon a major event (like a character death). In other words, if characters die you'll have to keep the group going in spite of the repercussions on the team.  That said, the first time you 'survive' the war with no team deaths you will feel like you've accomplished something.
Highly recommended. Great gameplay with randomly generated events means no two games are the same.

This game can get very frustrating, mostly because you can't save your progress, and autosaves are not when you want them to be. That being said, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game, and my advice is to play through it and try to get entertainment out of your mistakes, because you can't undo them and that's what this game is supposed to be about: a realistic simulation of survival in war times. In other words, I'm trying not to blame the game for me being spoiled by other games allowing me to load previous save points so often.   One thing I really like about the game is that each play through will be different. As for the gameplay, it kind of feels like a combination of the theme of The Walking Dead and mechanics of Craft the World.

My feels cannot be contained when I play this game. I suppose the main problem I have with this game is that it's so damn accurate. You go into a place that you think is full of bandits, you think you're making a pre-emptive strike against them and it turns out to be a woman who's trying to help her husband protect her children. Now her child is sobbing over her lifeless corpse and her father and husband is coming down the stairs. You book it out of there because you want your character to stay alive, but after you make it home you realize that you have nothing from that night and that the charcter you sent out to scavenge is horribly depressed. After all, he was only a celibrety chef, and nothing prepairs you for taking a ultimately innocent life.   In short, this game makes you decide. 'How far are you willing to go for survival?'

Great game, definitely worth playing and you will most likely get more play time out of it than most AAA games out there. I've just started playing it and hope to play more over the holiday break.  The most interesting thing I've found about This War of Mine is that it forces you to plan ahead. You're not going to hit a point where you think you've got a good handle on your current situation, and that you're comfortable knowing nothing is going to go wrong. You always have to think about what the next problem is going to be, and how you're going to plan for it. The game is well balanced, and the different elements (food, meds, weapons, trade..) that you have to manage are well balanced and each have a significant role to play in your planning for survival.  Each new game has fairly randomized events and locations, though as you get to a second or third play through you start noticing a pattern and that some of the events are scripted, for example,    going to the market in the first few days will have 3 armed looters, and going to the market at the end of your first week will always have a soldier trying to sexually assault a young girl  . This doesn't take away from the experience though, and will be mitigated with new content.  My first play through lasted 39 days, which isn't all that great, and it ended with the shooting death of one character, another lost to illness, one fleeing my shelter, and the last committing suicide.  Overall, definite purchase for anyone who likes strategizing in games, and a great addition to anyone's library.

Great game, took a few short games to get the learning curve. After that it was constant decisions about what to do each day. Do you build enough beds for everyone or board up the windows? Do you help your neighbors, what supplies can you give up to make this or trade for that. Should you rob from other survivors or aid groups to survive.  Your people will fight each other, over your choices. They'll get depressed, sick, injured, hungry and you'll have to decide to provide them with their vices or trade them away for supplies and materials.  You can avoid combat for most the game, with the exception of being raided at night. Nothing like having a safe stockpile, only to be raided and wind up losing most your food and a severly injured defender.  Combat itself could be improved a little, I only used the knife and pistol. The knife was constant click which wasn't bad and worked out better than using a pistol. For the pistol, it looks like there is an aim mechanic, but combat happens so quickly that I burned through six rounds, the bandit was still standing, and killed me with his shotgun.   When you start losing people, the game takes on another challenge.  When winter comes, get ready to break everything you can to keep the house warm, people fed, and fight off sickness.
Heartrending and intense. Every second counts, so make use of it! One of the most punishing games in terms of game-ending consequences to each decision.
Amazing game. After playing it I felt like I had actually lived in a war zone. I had to remind myself that I didn't need to hoard food in the real world.
Absolutely amazing game. Very atmospheric, great premise, well executed. I wholeheartedly reccomend it.

this war of mine is a really great game .. its very challenging to keep your people happy feed and in good heath.. they get sad depressed all of it .. i really love the game .. get the game if u dont have it yet for real u wont regret it ..

This game is the intellectual heir of Zafehouse. The mechanics are amazing and the freedom you experience is refreshing and though. You WILL fall in love with your characters and then mourn them when you loose them. Be it a sacrifice for the team, an unexpected illness or a scavenging hunt that went awry, you will miss them, and I dont mean their skills. The music and aesthetics of the game really help setting the mood for a cold, though war. Will you survive?

Absolutely phenominal game. For such a basic game at it's core, it's a really great game for the price. I've enjoyed countless scenarios, and I can always come back to this game after a break and pick right up!

A great game with an interesting take on war. This game makes you stay on your toes while you try to carefully keep a group of citizens alive. Through my gameplay, I mainly stayed in stealth-mode, but did try going in guns-first (Warning: Did not do so well with that...) This game does have you make certain choices, which is a positive in my book. These choices could affect your group's fragile stabability, your food/med supply, or nothing at all. I find great replay value in this game, and am overall estatic about this game.  My main con is my computer keeps giving me the blue screen of death after I log off!
A must-play for any Survival genre fan.

Just BUY this game! I have been hooked on the amazing enviroment and the need to survive. I go from day to day and can't stop myself from trying yet another night scavenging run. A great game that is a treasure in my game collection. Thanks guys keep coming out with games like this! Well done

This game really hits home with creativity and orginality. It has all the aspects you would expect but with a crooked twist as you view things from a different perspective. You learn to make hard decisions and it really just pulls you in the game where you feel as if you just sentenced the old man begging to stay with you to death by saying no.  You dont just survive in This War of Mine because it really makes you struggle. You never have enough food, medicine, and even coffee for everyone and the more you have the faster things can hit the fan.   10/10 and would buy again.

Wonderfully depressing. There are no other words as all decisions you make have their own reprocussions. Throughout the war, you're forced to consider your own responsibility as human beings against the general welfare of your team. Are you willing to kill to make it through another night?  Progressing through the initial stages of the game is relatively simple, yet reaching the end is surprisingly difficult. I do wish that the game had more replay value. As long as you have a general strategy, the gameplay is relatively similar across all characters.

- Went to an old apartment building that had been split in two. - People inhabiting the side I have to enter through. - I try to sneak in, some woman drops down out of the window above. - She yells 'Hey, what are you doing!?' - I lunge at her with a knife and silence her screaming. - Too late, someone heard. - Another woman comes down with a gun. - Oh ♥♥♥♥. - She drops her gun and starts sobbing over her friend's body. - I pick up the gun. Leave the woman to cry.  - Head upstairs to see if I can steal anything. - Come across another woman on lookout with a rifle, cursing some guy in the other ruined half of the building. - She turns around suddenly. Before she can say anything, I pump a shotgun into her chest. - She falls off the balcony, landing close to her other dead friend below. - I loot the place. - No regrets.  - After I leave, I realise all the people there were women. - I also remember reading something about shots being heard during the night. Explains the lootout. - Suddenly catch on that the women were likely hiding from a guy/some guys over in the other abandoned building. - Realise they may have just been defending themselves after a bad experience with males. - Remember saving a girl from 'sexual assault' two nights before. That ♥♥♥♥ happens in this City. - Realise that I just killed people who were scared and only hiding to stay safe from a guy that was possibly a 'sexual predator'. - All the regrets.  This game's bloody amazing if you like a game tugging on your heart strings.
You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become a heartless killer...

I don't think I can say anything that hasn't been said already.  As a game: entertaining, challenging, involving, emotive, full of replay-value.  More than that, it's pretty poignant look at the real, human costs of war. Where many games glorify combat as either an honorable pursuit or a struggle of 'Good vs. Evil', this game shows the strife, hunger, fear, sickness, bereavement and terrible struggle for survival in a wartorn world.  If you have an itchy trigger finger and a short attention span, this probably isn't the game for you.  If you like strategy, narrative and sometimes vexing challenges: I urge you to try this game.

The only complaints I have, are how often the characters say they 'miss going to the library' and the radio weather station saying, it's a good day to sit in your arm chair by the fireplace, with a cup of tea and a good book. Why? because I would miss many more basic things, like chrisp clean sheets after a wonderful soak in the tub...compared to going to the library. Also, there's no tea, nor are there fireplaces to sit in an armchair by! I love the game though, it's fun to play and replay! 4.75 out of 5!

Great game that will immerse you in a world where you're not the hero. You'll freak out, you'll run for your life and you'll always be sick and/or wounded and/or starving.   The biggest flaw is the lack of replayability, but the programmers seems willing to put a lot of time to continue to improve the game. This game seems on its way to become a gem.

There are far too many games where your choices really have an effect on the gameplay. Sure there's games like the Fallout series, where you lose Karma, but let's face it, you can deal with the challenges associated with playing like a psycopath. This War of Mine is not that type of game. If you go around cosistantly acting like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you're going to have a bad time. Your actions have reprecussions on he mental state of the group. If you keep doing it, the level of depression of certain members of your group could be so bad that they become unable to complete even basic tasks related to self preservation, or worse, they'll leave the group or commit suicide!   This War of Mine is a gritty, in your face game about the struggles of the masses in a war torn area. Where can I get food? Should I kill just to provide food for my people? Can I just steal to provide for my group? How will stealing/ killing defensless people affect the mental state of my group? Should I steal medication from the hospital I just donated medication to?  It's a well executed game that I really enjoyed. I do have a lot more play time than what steam says I do though as I play offline anytime I can while I'm at work on the ship. My reccomendation is that if you're looking for something that's not your common war simulator, but is a peek into the other side of the coin, then give this a try. I enjoyed it and I think you will too.

In most war games, you play as a soldier who just the saved the world from WWIII or an alien invasion. In this game, you are not a soldier who becomes the hero. You are survivors of a war who wants the pain to end. In This War of Mine, you must care for the survivors while managing resources to keep your group alive. I've played Spec Ops The Line and it is immersive games like this and Spec Ops The Line that gets me. I'm not a soldier or a civilian who survived a war but this game shows a grueling depiction of war and leaves me in emotions. Highly recommended.

BRUTAL. ENGAGING. SATISFYING.  This game does not hold your hand. This War of Mine is a challenge as much as it is a game. There is truly not another game done in this style the conveys they joy and dread of the choices you have to make. Wether it's helping someone or leaving them to fend on their own, wether you decide to loot and pillage everyone you come across just to survive or leave them with enough so your own people don't lose moral and break under the tough decisions that constantly need to be made.
