It is a good game but not good enough for its price. It's very hard if you are playing it for the first time, you just have to die a few times before you figure out how things work. It tells a story about 'a group of civilians trying to survive in a besieged city', you can really feel how the group respond to different events. However, when it comes to individuals, though I can see the effort is made (every character has their own story and different traits), the lack of immersion in the individual level is shown, players think more as a group rather than each individuals. I can't tell if this is intended or not, but in my opnion this is a flaw. Also, if more randomization and customisation (difficulties, customized characters and skill system) can be added this will be a great game. Once again this is a good game and is a very special one, but it is NOT great, there are still lots of improvements to be made.
Good game but i cant take it seriously enough (thats just me though) because i kill my people when i get bored and just end up restarting. 8/10

I never though I would enjoy this game as much as I did. When I first took a look, it seemed like a whole lot of micro management with a broken morality system. By the same token, few games have been able to elicit genuine emotion from me.  That said, this game is an instant classic in the steam library and a must have for those looking for a neat twist on the survival genre. You play as a group of survivors in a war torn city just trying to make ends meet. You’re lucky if you don't get shot by rebel soldiers or fellow scavengers, and luckier if you get to eat that day. Go through the day trying to mediate the needs of your own group with that of your neighbors and then journey into the night looking for supplies to keep yourselves going. There will be moral challenges, yes, but not necessarily any repercussions. Careful and clever players will find ways to commit crimes with impunity; however, this does not mean you will escape the emotional consequences, as your party attempts to cope with the atrocities they commit to survive in war. Teamwork is necessary, but others… they are expendable. Or, perhaps, you value their lives and will attempt, at all opportunities to be good and ethical – good luck.  Ultimately the game is a masterpiece, forcing a set of mind of survival and melancholia with its powerful imagery, music and dialogue. I’m only about 15 hours in, and I want more; and so will you.  Also, the soundtrack is free and it’s a pretty nice listen. So, there’s that.

Refreshing game play.Not the everyday shooter,rpg,zombie,dungeon crawler game we all play.I can only say it's the Odd world of 2014. Has great replayablity.My only concern is it is to short and was very sad when I beat it that fast.  DLC's??? Yes please!!
This game is depressing as hell. You will be forced to do bad things and feel bad about it or die in a few days. 10/10
Great game and very challenging :)

This War of Mine kept me hooked the entire time that I played it. While the game encourages multiple playthroughs, each playthrough carries its own weight, choices and consequences.  The only real drawback I feel with the game is, ironically, the exact reason why anyone would play This War of Mine: You are constantly at a shortage of the most essential items for survival - You'll never be warm enough, never have enough food, and never be safe enough to rest on your laurels. This War of Mine is a game that demands you constantly, actively manage your resources and absolutely nails the conflict of choice in a desperate situation that boils down to 'Should I save these items to survive another day, or should I use them now lest I be dead tomorrow?'

'No, please... stop... just take whatever you want, just don't hurt me anymore.'  Those were the last words a sick old lady told me as I slowly walked towards her to finish what I started, my group ws starving and injured and we needed what they had inside the house. It shouldn't have gone the way it did, but I didn't want them to call for help. I opened the door as they were talking to each other and I was met by an elderly man.  'How did you get in here? Please, leave, unless you have medicine, my wife is sick she doesn't need to be bothered.'   I hesitated, then in a desperate fit to get food for my starving group, I punched him square in the face.  'BANDIT, HONEY, GO HIDE DOWNSTAIRS.'   The old man tried to run, maybe for a weapon, but I must have staggered him since he fell over at the foot of the stairs, I quickly caught up to him and finished him. 'Please.. don't hurt my wi-' He didn't get to finish as I beat him where he lay, I quickly went downstairs to find the wife. I went back upstairs into their bedroom and while scavenging I found a letter, I don't remember the exact words but it was to their Grandchild, how they were comforting his concerns on the state of his grandmother's health, how Bernard, the old man I murdered downstairs, was going to fix his swing when he visited later.   Soon after I managed to find the supplies I needed, and once I was done satisfying my hunger and bandaging 2 of my friends, I sat down and remembered what I had done... I wish I didn't need to do it, I want this nightmare to be over, 'It's alright' Bruno told me, 'you did what you felt to help us survive, now get some rest.'  Pavle after standing guard all night, mumbled to himself as he laid in bed 'Why'd you have to do it Marko? You'll never forget what you've done after the war is over.'  This was only 5 days in and we were raided 3 nights in a row. I did redeem myself a little by stabbing a soldier to death by surprise who attempted to defile a woman, But nevertheless, I am a monster.

Holy wow! Intense game about survival during war times. You aren't a soldier. You can't fight well. Most of the time, you don't even have a gun. Scrounge at night for resources while balancing keeping your survivors fed, healthy, and alive.  Oh, and watch out for winter.

One the best games I have played. Is in my top 10 for sure.

This game is really good, but not in an 'enjoyable' fashion. I know that might sound weird at first but bare with me. This is the type of game that when you play it you get engrossed in whats going on...the story behind each character...the want and need to survive in any way you can (even if it means being sad or depressed for a while.) Let me tell you a story about what I mean further below.  This game is essentially the sims, mixxed with a survival aspect, and a 'RNG Moral Choice story driver similar to FTL' in your own actions...its worth the play, and if it was modded so tha you could add in your friends, create characters, etc etc....it would have a LOT more replay value than it already does....  =========================================  (possible soilers even though its mostly random) My current story (1/8/15) I started out with a team that were mostly scavenger based....fast runner, guy that can carry a lot, and a cook. Each night you send out one person to scavange for 'things to survive.' After 20 or so days, id given a girl (stealthy one at that) haven in the house. This is both good and bad. its good because that means that if i need to sneak around a place, i can send her out instead of my heavy hauler....but bad because now i have to feed her and have a bed for her too. Anyway, 20 or so days in i no longer had any 'safe / happy' areas left to scavange from....this meant I was forced to either wait and hope for the best...or go visit an elderly couples place. i did so and proceeded to rob them blind. Thier son tried fighting back...I then was forced to kill all 3 of them (passivly on the elderly couple as i took all thier stuff to live) and that lasted me another 10 days or so...the food started running out, and that meant the other elderly couple that had lost their son in the war was the next stop. I had a choice, steal their stuff and save 4 lives...or let the old woman and man die from stealing their medications and food. Again, I was forced to steal from them...but now I had no one to take from but a hospital, church, or a warehouse full of thugs. Thinking that my stealthy girl could get in get a full pack and run....i sent her...sadly she's dead now and im back to the original 3. War is hell...

Survival, booze, cigs, starting from nothing and working your way to relaxing with everything needed, this game is awesome. Would totally love add ons to this game. Maybe extend the time and get more areas to explorer. Now the only thing I have left is to get each picture with Survive on it!

This game is a master peice that will test your moral limits and show just how far you are willing to go to survive.   We were running out of food, Sick and hungry I decided to check out the supermarket. I sneaked around picking up what I could, Hiding from the soldiers guarding the place. I heard a girl, speaking to a soldier, saying she needed food for her family. I watched through the door as this soldier made a move on the girl in exchange for food. She refused telling him she needed to go home. I watched as he beat her with his rifle. I let her be the distraction so that I may gather what I needed for my group.  I went home with a full pack, and the memory of that girl, Her family now had to live with out her.

One of the best games i've ever played, so simple, but yet so hard. Expect to die!   Very time consuming, but so frustratingly satisfying. Learn from your mistakes, watch your group deteriorate and fall in to depression as the war forces you to make some of the hardest choices. Learn to love and hate the characters, and be sad to see some of them go. Will you save the weakest links? Or will you let your darwinian side take the best of you?  Just as you thought you had it all going, the harsh reality of the war raging outside will tear it all away in a heart beat. Your closest friends might turn on you and leave you with nothing. Scavangers might steal all you've worked so long and hard for. The cold might choke the life force out of you, and you will be forced to send children starving home to their sick parents. Might be one day left of the war for all you know, but that day might as well be your last.   No saving. No retrying from checkpoint. You get one shot in making it through, as you play the real victims of war in this epic survival strategy game.. Hours 'wasted', but hours so deeply enjoyed!  10/10 Well worth the money!  (ps: If all you are in to are FPS and/or sport games, this game might not be for you, worth a try anyway though!)

This is my first game review so here it goes.  I tend to shy away from the indie games as many feel rather limited in scope. However after a friend told me about 'This War Of Mine' I went ahead and tried it. Dam what a game I mean its dark, sad yet beautiful.  The fact is this indie game makes games from the big mega companies look lacking and simple.  After 23+ hrs I can tell you the only con with this game is that it ends and a bit to soon.  Good Luck
This game is so damn addicting... Ive gotten other family members into it now. Definitly worth the price.

This is a good game, it has a great concept, but for 20 dollars it could have been pulled off better.  There is plenty to like about this game it is unique, has that addictiveness that makes you want to play for hours, it is challenging and makes you think, and about 5 mins in i was already hooked and ended up pulling an all nighter. But it has its problems, and after awhile you will start to feel frustrated. some things just don't make sense, like how i have to filter rain water when i am going to be boiling it while using it to cook anyways, or how a wooden board takes up the same space in my backpack as some leaves do, but these are minor issues.. The main frustration with this game is the combat system, it is wonkey, you can sneak up on a sleeping bandit with a knife, and stab him in the neck, and he still sometimes can get up, grab his gun, and kill you; or all of his friends hear you silently stab him and come kill you.. The combat system combined with the permanent death mechanic makes this game very frustrating.. There is a difference between a game being challenging, and poorly designed gameplay mechanics.. I still recomend this game, as the problems could easily be fixed, but I would wait for a sale.

(tl;dr - this is an excellent game, highly challenging, with strong atmosphere and a real sense of how difficult it is for ordinary people to survive in a war zone)  I came to This War of Mine having just finished reading a book about the Siege of Leningrad in 1941-42. It turned out to be the perfect preparation.  TWOM is not like other survival games, with an emphasis on shooting your way out of trouble. In fact, it's more than possible to go for an entire game without once experiencing any kind of combat. If that makes the game sound easy or boring, think again. RIght from the outset, your small group of survivors is left to fend for themselves, using any means of staying alive - scrabbling through piles of debris for scraps of food, wood, material, mechanical parts, anything to make their lives in their half-bombed shelter bearable.  During the day it's too dangerous to leave their shelter, so the survivors spend their time building makeshift workshops, eating barely-edible meals made up of dead rats and scavenged vegetables, melting snow to make fresh water, and playing the guitar to relieve the gloom. Occasionally someone comes to the door to offer help, or to barter goods, or to present a risky opportunity with high reward if it comes off.  During the night, one survivor in the group must go on a mission to find supplies. This could mean raiding an abandoned supermarket, ransacking a shelled building with dead bodies still inside, or sneaking through a hotel filled with dangerous, armed gangsters. There's only a limited amount of time, and a limited amount of stuff the survivor can carry - so it comes down to hard choices. Take this extra piece of food, because everyone in the group is hungry? Or sacrifice it in order to take these mechanical parts which will enable the group to build a water filter?  The game never quite gives you enough, so the resources are always stretched, and these hard choices have to be made every day. You find yourself willing a trader to come to the door so that you can barter your precious medical supplies (which you might need one day) just for an extra piece of food. And, of course, as soon as you've done that, one of your group falls ill... The game further complicates things by triggering random raids on your shelter, so that even when you think you're safe the little you have can be taken away from you. You can literally be left without food, and with half your group injured, in a single night.  It's details like these (and the fact that the game gives you no instructions whatsoever) that have led some people to complain that the game is too difficult; and the Steam forums are abuzz with people requesting the developers add in extra options and amendments to make life easier. But, in fact, once you've grasped the basics and played through a few times, a clear path to victory does emerge (although it'll be different each time). The game can almost be too easy for a seasoned player - but the challenge has been increased in the latest version, as you get to try your luck with different groups of survivors, each more helpless and limited than the previous set.  Aside from gameplay, the game is beautifully rendered in cross-section pseudo-3D graphics, with monochrome shading and a highly plausible design. You really do feel like you're in the middle of war-torn Sarajevo (the game is set in the fictional East European city of Pogoren, but the allusions to the war in Bosnia are obvious). The atmosphere throughout is gloomy, thoughtful and just the right side of depressing. You really do become attached to your little band of survivors, each with his or her own skills and drawbacks. To complete the picture, each survivor has a backstory which is revealed gradually thoughout the game, giving them a rounded personality and making the player identify more strongly with each of them.  The emphasis in the game is on realism (which is why it's hard - surviving in a war zone is no picnic, after all). Where realism is sacrificed, it enhances the gameplay, putting limits on the player which would make the game too easy if they weren't there.  TWOM isn't (usually) a heart-thumping, high-octane, shoot-em-up wartime action game; there's no shortage of them around. What it is is something rather more thought-provoking. When you take away the guns and give them all to your opponents, what do you have left? How do the little people, the non-combatants, the citizens with no access to food, warmth or weapons, survive in a situation like this? You'll lose your first few games, most likely - all your survivors dead, your heart broken. But play on, because when you finally get your people through to the end of the war, all the emotion you invested in them will be repaid.  Thoroughly recommended.

Very nice game that touches your heart in a sad why and shows you some part of wars and what it takes to survives. Basically it is very similar to the SIMs in the sense of pleasing your character and make them survive the war (50 days)  worth buying at least when on sale!
I played 16 hours straight in 1 sitting

War survival game that is mainly about micro-managing the resources you obtain by scavenging, trading, stealing or killing. Good decision making and management of resources will allow you to survive. What is really engaging about this game is how the moral choices are hidden within the game itself. You can end up in situations where scavenging does not work, and you will be pushed to the edge and maybe, eventually you have to steal or kill to survive. The game also does a good job in making you emotionally invested in your decisions.  It is a fantastic game albeit a fairly steep price point, but I did buy the game from the humble store sale at 15% off. It has a considerable amount of replayability as you can try different ways to survive. You could also try different paths of human morality.
Good game, but still have Crash and bug on it, need to fix it 8/10

I finished playing after three hours and thoroughly felt my chest grow heavier. Each day became an increasing struggle for lives I felt emotionally attached to. You really grow on this game, and it forms a place in your heart that tugs at the very inside of your gut. It exposes the horrors of war from the eyes of those cannot protect themselves and those who would take advantage of them. This is certainly worth a playththtough.

Very fun game, I have spent entirely too much time on it.  This game is a 'thinking' game, though the first few hours spent on it can be highly 'reactive' to the enviroments you are put in. And it is a bit emotional starting out. Maybe the music/backgrounds/etc, but you can get pretty caught up in it.  Bad part is... eventually you know the whole game. The ins and outs of each location. What to do if it is winter. What series of steps to take with each character, etc. The emotion leaves and you robotically click, only on occasion having to do some thinking.  The developers did a fantastic job randomizing it enough so that it takes some time to get stale, but it does get stale.  And then what? I want to keep playing but I want new scenes and situations. Now I have some sort of odd monkey on my back, sigh.   Looking forward to the next release!

A refreshing change of pace, there are a plenty of these scavenge / collect resources / build shelter type games available but TWOM manages to balance the gameplay perferctly while revealing hints of the survivors story as their situation worsens from day to day.  There are clues in the game that hint at possible future DLC releases (what's the deal with the locked backpack space?) but what you do get is a great little game.

There are clues in the game that hint at possible future DLC releases (what's the deal with the locked backpack space?) but what you do get is a great little game.

I had already scavenged the supermarket on a previous raid, finding it to be uninhabited and with some locked cabinets blocked by rubble in the basement, I had planned my looting stragegy for the next few nights.. and so I returned with a shovel, crowbar and lock pick. Only this time there was somehting happening, a young girl scavenging in the trash - watched by a solider, things were about to turn nasty. I peaked through the keyhole to watch as the scene played out, hoping I wouldn't have to intervene - and then he went for her. Unlike some other reviewers I guess I got lucky on this one, opened the door - shovel in hand! - clanking him on the head - the girl ran - I followed - I never saw her again.   Other than the feeling of The Sims At War at times - this is a fantastic game, it never lets you get settled, you never have enough and as soon as you think you have it figured out, it reminds you that there's a war going on, anything can happen.   I made it all the way through with a starting four - lost two, the school teacher and the scientist - he was wounded early on and never really recovered - both were terminally ill with medicines lethally difficult to com by. They did not die until day 40 - 2 days before the end of the war.
This is the best side scroller game of its kind! Spent days playing this game on end without any sleep! :D
Not only is the game interesting and challeneging. It's a lot of fun! I have very little hours on it yet I can see myself playing it a lot more. Can't wait for future updates! :D

Let me start by saying that I thought that the 'survival' genre was on its way out of popularity before I started playing this game. That being said, This War of Mine is a brilliant minimalist survival experience that will have you playing through multiple times. The basic premise of the game is simply to survive the horrors of a war-torn city experiencing an armed rebellion. To do this you must control a cast of characters and fortify a shelled out home to endure the coming days. The characters you get are pre set, but you unlock more combinations of characters as you progress through the game. Each character has basic needs; hunger, sleep, and their general health (ie: keeping their wounds treated and sick characters healthy). Some characters also have additional needs that make taking care of them slightly more difficult, such as an addiction to cigarettes. These needs and wants are what will influence your decision making as you progress through the game.  This War of Mine focuses on survival, but also allows players to choose the easy way out of a situation by sacraficing their humanity in order to live. What I mean by this is that you will encounter situations where you can easily obtain food or medical supplies, but you must steal or kill to obtain them. The option to scavenge and create your own supplies exists, but if someone is dying from a gunshot wound, then you may have no choice but to rob the doctor down the street who is doing all he can to treat civilians who are injured in the conflict. Performing such an act will have a negative influence on morale, and has a chance to break the character who performed the deed, rendering them useless for some time and possibly even pushing them to suicide.  The game is not flawless. One big problem that I had was that little to no game mechanics are explained. There is no legend to tell players what icons mean, and combat is a veritable trial by fire that will most likely claim the life of the first character that encounters it. Once you have become a veteran all this will mean nothing, but as a new player to the game it can be frustrating. That is certainly the biggest error I have detected, and it is not enough to stop me from labeling this as an excellent game.  What is being presented to us as gamers is more than just another 'get wood, make fire, cook meat, live' survival game; it is The Sims meets Fallout. Control your party's emotions and physical and mental state of being. Juggle your characters needs, make or steal the weapons you need to survive, and ultimately do what you need to in order to live through the war.  9/10: highly reccomended.

I feel bad playing this game and I have no fun when doing it. I was really expecting some fun and a more sedentary way of life with no much harm and danger.  This game gave me nothing of this. I'm not playing this game anymore, I feel tired when doing it and that's why the developers made a good job.  This game is for the ones who are seeking for real challenge and immersion, so, if you are looking for fun you may not find in this game, yet, you may get attached to it somehow, until you find out that your people are nearly wiped.  I'm not qualified to give a score to this game as this genre is not my strong point, but I would definitely recommend it if you understood my previous guidelines.

I have nothing new to add beyond the other positve reviews of this. The entire time micromanaging and making desicions based on the emotional and physical conditions of your survivors and what supplies they have, while considering the dangers and state of the other violent or helpless survivors across the city make for a stressful game that I would recommend to anyone. 10/10.

Human Reality Simulator 2014   I believe this is a game that everyone should play at least once. The game summarizes in three word are distress,gloomy and morbid. The War of Mine perfectly delivered it message. How war effect innocent peoples trapped in the vicious cycle of mankind, Word of advice. You will not feel good in this game. Never, It only gives you a sigh of relief knowing you will survive for one more day, The game will leave you doubting every action you take.  Will you steal food from an elderly couple who just wanted to survive or will you steal it or take it by force (even kill) to save your group who hasn't been eating for 4 days straight? Well, that is what war do to you.
One of the best survival games I've ever played.. Truely an emotional rollercoaster of a game.
Fantastic game. Only way it could be better is if they added a multiplayer option.

Ok, this game is damned :D I survived 23 days with the scarcest of resources, always at the brink of complete obliteration, always fearing that it is going to be the last day. Food? Barely to help minimal sustenance. Meds? Too limited to be useful. All characters were constantly battling depression. News on the radio were always grim. This game actually makes you feel like the whole world is against you. AND AFTER ALL THAT, WINTER CAME.

Having only played around 6 hours of the game, I wouldn't be able to give a very complete review. From a starters perspective, I can say that the game is gripping (and addictive to begin with), it's very tense and builds drama up rather successfully. I also found, the game doesn't really teach you how to play (which arguable supports the realism), for me, this adds to the enjoyment slightly, I like figuring things out on my own and failing once or twice means I get to learn and improve my gameplay the next time. Another positive I found was that death really is appreciated, if you kill someone innocent, then your character may become depressed or upset and really contemplate what they've done. Also - if you run out of cover in a dangerous area, you're going to get shot, and death is death in this game, there's no going back (which isn't always a bad thing, with one less mouth to feed). Some games ruin the realism of a game by allowing you to respawn over and over, but here, death is certainly taken seriously. The trading system is also very handy and in my opinion nicely balanced and easy to use. Different characters/scenarios make the game seem different and real each time.  As for some negatives, there isn't anything massive really, I think, even after 6 hours, the landscape seems slightly repetitive, which may change as I continue to play, but I'm not sure whether it will change drastically, I'm just hoping it does. Although I do believe every world is randomly generated so I might be clutching at straws here, but everytime I've spawned in, it's been in the same building and the buildings I visit have all been the same (with slightly different people or circumstances in each playthrough). I may just be slightly confused over the progression of the game. The combat system, well, it's not really a system, can be slightly annoying, and for me, unexplained, which is fine, because ultimately you are playing as civilians and are not supposed to be a combat specialist. Just at some points it felt extremely clunky and one sided. However, I do think the key is sneaking up on people and getting them that way, and in fairness, I was a footballer with a spade, against a soldier with an AK-47, but I did sneak up on him, however after that first hit, he just kept hitting me with his ak and frustratingly I couldn't get another hit in until I was lethally wounded.   Looking forward to playing more and updating this review.

Surprisingly addictive. You can't save mid day so the feeling of 'just one more day' leads to hours of gaming. I like the take on a different PoV from usual war games. In charge of a group of civilians, your goal isn't to kill and destroy but to survive. Very challenging when other people are willing to kill to protect their scraps.
If EA made a Sims: War-torn Nightmare expansion, it might be something like this. Harrowing, but brilliant.
Awesome, 10/10, would hype again.
I don't review games much but this one is definately worth getting!
Great Simulator of real war surviving ,presenting nice surviving dilemas. Full of variety , was very very funny. Nice fresh air to gaming :)
very good game would recommen to play, havent finished yet ;( but its fun and doesnt get boring after a while! ;)

I will keep it short and sweet. I just started playing and wow what a game! This is a true testament to the war and the atmosphere is absolutely brilliant. Really puts you into a different perspective of the wartime life compared to that of a soldier. You are a surviver.. almost a harder duty in its own right. Please give this game a chance I would love for you to have a wonderful experience! :D

This game is beautifully thought out. It gives the player a lot of freedom, but still pushes him through hard decisions and small victories. Contrary to most simulation games, you can't just go through trying to maximize your score, you get attached to the characters' struggles, and have to let in some humanity.  Though this game carries the 'indy' label, it feels very polished and coherent from start to finish.  With such a dark and realistic theme, I was afraid that it would make me depressed; but in the end, it was actually a pleasant experience. --not for children, thougt.  Definitely a good game.
I've been waiting a long time for a game just like this and here it is! Cannot fault it!

this game is so much fun, and could be play in so many way to whoever is thinking about buying this game is definitely worth it even though the graphic isnt as good as many high end games this day the game play was amazing the struggles among different people the allocation of limited resources this game is amazing and i am still playing it after finished the first around
Truely amazing game for anyone. Especially if you like things that are dark, real and make you think.
I recommend playing this game while eating a sandwich. It's the best of times.
Worth it! I couldnt stop playing it!

Let me preface this by saying that it is a good game. It is more than worth twenty dollars and so very much worth your time. The game itself plays and feels exactly how you would think; a dark, gloomy oppressive world that wants you not to survive. The moral choices you face can be difficult but it really is only limited by you own morality. If you aren't the type to get immersed into your games, then you likely will be unaffected by the old man begging you not to steal his sickly wife's medicine. or the father pinned by a sniper desperately trying to reach his sickly infant. That's not to say that it takes away from the overall enjoyment of the game. You could still find plenty of fun from managing your houshold, or tough decisions such as: two of three survivers are ill and it is the dead of winter. You have no food and no medicine. What will you prioritize? You may not find both. Overall the best analogy is a hellish game of The Sims. Even if the game doesn't strike a heartstring, there is enough to like and fret over. Definitely worthy of all the recommendations.

Kat is almost completely unresponsive. Bruno, all he does is sleep. No one has seen Pav for over 2 days since he offered to help a child find his mother. for the first few days, it seemed like gravy. We even found a guitar to play and a bottle of cheap booze. We were content to ride this speed bump out. Well, obviously, we never read the survivors account of Stalingrad, and trying to survive with our bare hands. This is the toughest time and most depressing time I've had playing a 'game'. Those poor old people, ...what did I do to them to get in their kitchen? It's no wonder that Kat can't even move anyore and doesnt even acknowledge our presense, she just sits there with her head in her hands....well, I'm going to try to sleep, if we don't find some food tonight scavanging, ...well, I don't want to eat one of the rats that are looking at me like a meal.......

I would say it's by far one of the best games I've ever played. But there are many cons to the game the developers should look into.  1. Game length is abit short for my liking   2. Character special traits should be more distinct. (Example bargaining. Katia only has an advantage of one more component over the rest in trading and the cook cooks with the same ingredents as the rest.)  3. Marketplace trading is absurd. I can buy up the whole place with just one bandage  4. Difficulty towards the middle and ending it is way too easy as i have accumulated more than 20 meat, 30 vegetables, 12 bandages, 15 medicine and many more stuff. (the only thing i'm constantly short of is component)  5. If i have an Assault Rifle i can kill 6 armed militia in a single scavanging hunt. (I don't know if that's a good thing or bad thing)  6. Cigarettes and Coffee have little to no effect on the survivors as far as i can see.   But overall this game is super awesome. Really puts you in the shoes of a civilian in a war torn country. Abit pricey to be honest but definitely recommend everyone to get it.  Edit: Game gets pretty hard when i played it again and again. Had to let the old man die because i don't have anymore bandages left for him. Sleeping doesnt heal wounds or sickness it only delays them. Most of the time the survivors are either sad or depressed, sometimes even broken. No more central market where you are buy everything with a bandage. Still managed to complete it.

I love it. Hard, difficult, sad, permadeath... but it's rewarding. An incredibly deep experience. Night scavenger phases are tense and exciting, while managing the goods and the survivors during the day is a real challenge. I expected more of a free-roaming experience and it is not, but even so the gameplay is very original and full of possibilities. I highly recommend it.
This is like don't starve...but unlike don't starve this game actually makes sense

Harrowing and depressing, but deep and meaningful. This War of Mine feels a little like XCom, in that you come to care about your characters and want them to survive, but this is a game about decisions and scarcity, and you never have what you need. You never have enough food, or water, or supplies, and somebody always has to go without... and sometimes that kills. In this game, good deeds rarely pay off at all, and more often than not you are punished for them mercilessly. This is a game about the brutal realities of living in a warzone, and the horrible acts that desperation drives human beings to.  Should you play this? Yes. It has that 'one more turn' (-like) quality that so few games achieve these days - resources are scarce and stakes are always high. But don't expect to walk away from a play session happy; this game, like it's subject matter, is all about loss, melancholy, and sadness. Good luck and godspeed.
Day 10 Raid a supermarket. Kill a Soldier like a ninja. Pick his gun. Kill another Soldier like Rambo  Badass game 10/10

Definitely a favourite game of the year for me. This game is thought-provoking and every action you take carries consequences - which I find unique in games. You can't just go into a building and shoot everyone up to obtain supplies. You really have to decide whether or not it is worth the risks - depression and wounds. When you have a character lethally wounded and not very useful on scavenges - do you sacrifice them?  When you see a girl being ♥♥♥♥♥ by a soldier in the supermarket, do you kill him or use her as a cover to loot the building? When the milita come to your door to ask if your neighbour had been stealing from international aids, do you lie to them or tell them the truth and get cigarettes and some canned food?  These are just a few of the really difficult decisions you have to make throughout the game.  After 4 run throughs, I finally survived and the war ended on day 50. I think I got really lucky in the beginning when I started off with 4 characters rather than usually the 3. Also all 3 weren't smokers or coffee drinkers so they didn't get depressed when I didn't focus on gathering cigarette supplies.  I will keep on playing this game over and over.

A gripping game about trying to survive in a war-torn city. Superb concept, solid mechanics, great art and overall a harrowing but highly engaging experience. It's like watching a sad movie or reading a book where horrible things happen - it's not 'fun' per se, but definitely a worthwhile experience.  To get the most out of the game, make sure not to look up any strategies or wikis for the first few hours. Once you understand all the systems it's not too hard to always survive. It's still a good *game* like that, but in my case the first few hours of flailing around trying not to die while not crossing too many moral boundaries is what left the strongest impression.   Highly recommended to anyone who's looking to understand more about the world and themselves.
Already on my second playthrough of this game. Great survival game, getting hurt or sick really impacts you in this game so be careful.

Incredible, just a fantastic game. very well made and thought out and the traiding system is perfect! I don't ever buy games off sale but i took a chance on this title as i'm a sucker for bleak gritty games and survival rpgs. totaly worth it, so pleased with the game as a whole. If i could add to it however, i would love a bit of character creation or somthing to keep it fresh long term.

This game will pit you with a group of civilians with thier own opinions, and skills. You will have to survive by getting food, water, and materials to build and improve your house. The war makes it harsh and you will not survive by being the 100% good guy. You will have to steal from people and you may kill someone who didnt deserve it. This game will test your survivablitly and test your moral as your civilians become devestated by the war. Pros: The game has a good story and atmoshere The game will make you regret choices and feel awesome at others It has a unique style to the game and gives you a diffrent look at war. Cons: It is difficult at times but this can easily be delt with The graphics itself are ok. There are glitches in the game like someone falling from a ladder once you hit them with a melee and characters sitting on nothing  All in all a great game. Please do not use this as a good review, I was just saying what I think about the game. If you want a review, please look up another review for this game. Thank you and be careful, war is hell, and you may not make it through.
Great game, i really like the setting and the struggle of the day to day survival. I recommend it implicitly!

Im loving This War of Mine at the moment, I would have played it all night through until the morning if I didnt have things to do in the real world!   A short review -  The game has a beautiful feel and feels very well made, with a high level of detail in how the civilians under your control deal with the world around them.  They become hungry, tired, ill, wounded, sad, depressed, cold - and it is your job to help them overcome that.  As a lover of survival and base building type RPGs I would highly recommend this game!!!

I honestly though i was going to regret this game purchase. I mean sure its 20$, but DAMN its amazing!  You start off the game with 3 people and set out to survive. It's really hard if you don't think tactically. (RNG plays a large part in the events that occur)   Well anyways the meat is trying to create an self sufficient Utopia for your war-torned group of survivors to live.   BE WARNED: There is alot of emotional value.   Now go buy it.
Perfect, deep game. You will see war from completly different perspective - most probably your perspective in real live. Highly recommended!

In war you will die like a dog for no good reason' Well I can say that all of my characters died and none of them for a good reason, I only survived 18 days. At first everything was so simple, the supplies in my house were fine and I can loot abandonded houses when the food was running low, but then things changed.  The first time I commited evil was in an old house, I had pavle looting it and found it to be inhabited, the people saw me after I stole some of their things, they tried to make me leave, I saw this as a threat, so I killed an approaching man with a gun, after this a woman cowered in fear and begged for mercy, I killed her, she wanted to kill me right? I then realised what I had done, but I was so desperate for supplies I kept going. My character had breif depression after that. I thought I had it bad then.  I was very low on supplies, a new girl asked to join my group of three and promised to pull her wait if we deided to take her in, I accepted her request. Immediently afterwards she bacame sick, I then had no medicine left.  Then my character Marko went out scavenging, there were people there. They seemed to be nice but I couldn't find what I needed searching through the rubble. Bruno was desperate for bandages, Pavles depression had been lashed out on him even though he was trying to help. I thought it would be ok if I just saw was in the private property, it would be right? Wrong. I looked through it, there was no bandages, the man whose property it was then tried to kill me. And he did. Marko died.That loss was tolerable. I had Arica scavenging for supplies, I hit the jackpot, but as I tried to leave there was a barred door, I could have easly gone around it however I intended on returning here so I decided to break it open, as I did a raider hearrd. That was Arica's end. That really did it for Pavle, he had no chance left, he just kept breaking down even more, I had to have Bruno do all of the work. They were doing ok, then Bruno died. Suicide. Things were really bad then, every night when Bruno scavenged everthing I had would be stolen.  Eventullay though tt didn't matter, I just took important things with me. Things were really looking up, I had nearly everything I needed, Bruno was well fed and had plenty of sleep, I thought I may actually be able to survive for quite a while still. There was just one problem.  Depression. Bruno commited suicide. I survived 18 days.  10/10 Would have all my characters commit suicide or die for stupid reasons again. Really though. I got more depressed than they did. It was amazingly captivating and a completely incredible experience.
It takes a good game to make me come back for more even if it makes me sad.

If you're looking for a game that you can keep all of your morals intact, don't choose this game.   After a decent playthrough reaching 20 days, I had lost a few of my group to bandits, illness and starvation, but what really got to me is how I lost my last remaining character.   Breaking into a building I presumed was abandoned, I began to loot all possible items, I noticed that the loot was really good and very common but I carried on pushing into the ruins. I ended up bumping into two men who was nice to me and offered to trade so we did and I got a little desperately needed food in return for some ammo and water. I then went upstairs to loot from the unsuspecting party but there was one of them standing on a balcony, I questioned if what I was doing was right and of course the answer was NO.  However, I crept to the man and pulled out my hatchet and swung for him, he turned as I swung so he didn't do immediately and silently, he then retaliated to which we fought and I won but in doing so he fell backwards down a gap in the 4-story building and landed straight between his trading buddies who soon sprinted upstairs and brutally F***KED me up.   The moral of this game is don't trust anyone, not even yourself. Keep morals intact. Don't lose sight of who you are. IT'S NOT JUST A GAME.

What a realistically depressing game. Not that it's a bad thing, but it really hits you hard when the cold hard truth sets in, that war is hell. The game itself is really well made. Production quality is top notch, reminds me a bit of the Sims. It's actually a bit scary too. Not being able to see or know what lurks in the next room is pretty frightening, even from the sideview prespective.   Great game, although I could only play it in short spurts here and there. Too much tragedy and sadness for prolonged play, lol.

That is a really nice game.Because the style of the game is easy to control.And everything is close to real life,inclue the emotiom of the characterics.But it needs some fighting system to full of the game.But it`s a pretty nice give.It worths the price.
Truly a one of a kind indie game there is. 10/10 - ♥♥♥♥ Emil and the Girl !

This is truly a challenging game, and while I love it, there were a few very key issues that I experienced in my first two play throughs. The first play through, I reached only 16 days, losing a total of 4 characters. The second, 37 days and losing 6 characters.  #1. Even though I accidentally drew aggressive attention in one area, I returned with a different character to trade, and that character was treated as if they were the original trespasser and killed. #2. Fist fights killing - three hits and you're dead from none knife/gunfire. Very unrealistic. Also receiving any slight wound from fist-fights can turn into more severe degrees of being wounded. It would seem to be more inclined to make the game difficult, but it feels less believable to me personally. #3. Entering the hospital, my scavenger was told to bring any salvaged supplies to the doctor. I found medicine in the hospital and took it to give to the head doctor. He then proceeded to yell at me that those were his and he called for help, ending in the death of yet another character.  Regardless, I plan on playing this game more and find it quite enjoyable despite the frustrations.

It's fun, but starting to become a bit frustrating. I'm on day 20 of my first playthrough at the time of writing. Scavenging is becoming increasingly difficult because now I'm down to just hostile areas, but I've had enough trade materials to spare that I'm doing fine on meds, food and supplies all around with the little bits I can bring back from scavenging. Honestly I should be able to maintain ok for at least 5 more days without violence of any sort, though there is a whole area of goodies I want to get into that is guarded... I haven't had any issues with illnesses, I guess I just got really lucky there according to some of the other reviews. Twice I had someone come up with 'slightly sick' and they just slept it off. I also haven't had to make any hard choices at all. They've all been pretty obvious and I've had the goods at the time to be able to do whatever comes at me. I've only killed maybe 4 people so far and didn't feel bad about it and my people were ok with it too. 2 of the 4 were bandits I killed around day 15 or so (killing them made my people happy), one was a soldier trying to get a girl to give him a 'favor' for food (which was another obvious choice and made my people happy), and one was just a guy guarding some pretty loots we needed early in the game so everyone felt it was worth it to off him. I regret nothing so far.

BRUTAL. ENGAGING. SATISFYING.  This game does not hold your hand. This War of Mine is a challenge as much as it is a game. It's got a slow pace, but the amount of player investment makes it seem like a rollercoaster. I found myself saying 'just one more day' until it was finished.  11 bit Studios has struck the perfect balance between gameplay and player involvement. I wouldn't pay more that $20 because of the time it takes to complete. Having said that, it is extremely replayable if you think you can handle the ride a second time.  10/10
This is the most addictive and fun to play game for a long time. Oldschool at its finest + very good music and atmosphere. I recommend! :)
What a game 11/10! ING
Very fun the first few times playing it but it kind of got repetitive and needs more content but very great potential!

I believe this game is very good and is a step in the right direction for a good time. You will struggle to survive. You will see certain aspects of humanity you dont see in everyday life. You will question your morals. You will make useful items in your quest to survive. You will forsake the backpack and its rigamoroe. You will be glad you played and expereanced this game.

Depressing, difficult, and showing the side of war we see very little of. Many choices to go through and extremely thought provoking.  Art work is decent but you could easily squeeze a bit more detail out of everything, even with the 'sketched' art style. Controls are a bit odd and wonky at times, mostly during combat.   8/10

This game .... is too realistic.  I wanted to just go stab people and take their stuff, like I would in any other game, but this game factors in how actual human beings might feel about doing stuff like that. Wtf.  10/10 would cry myself to sleep again.
Extremely polished and brilliant game.  I found a loophole when you are on your own to protect your stash from raiders. I hope the developers may find a way to fix this.

One of the best indie game I have play. An survival game is not thin in story telling. However, please fix some of bug in the game. No matter where I visit, I am automatically count as intruder by non hostile NPC. I suspect it was because to I exited the game when I enter combat mode at night because I got something else I have to attend to. If you are hungry, will you steal? And if your life depends on it, will you kill?  Its never black nor white, and its especially true in This War of Mine. You are a few survivors, banded together in a time of war. You need to gather supplies and craft what little you can to improve your hideout and maintain your health.   But what happens when you get injured and you have no bandages? What happens when you get ill and you have no medicine? Will you give what little you have to help a sick woman whom you don't even know? Or will you give that little food you managed to gather to hungry children who just happened by?  This game is all about choices. Every night, you can send one of your survivors to scavange a location in the city. You need to choose which one you send, you need to decided what you bring back (because you have limited backpack slots), then you need to decide what you spend those resources on. There is a good amount of things you can craft: A bed to give your survivors good rest, water collector to cook meal or produce alchool, planks of wood to secure your hideout, etc. But you never know what next location is going to become available, what you will be able to bring back, if one or more of your survivors are going to become ill or wounded. And with every action comes a consequence. You are not in a game where you can kill all 'bad guy' just because you can.   On a content note: There are a good amount of different survivors (about a dozen), each having a special skill that can make it invaluable to survive. Everyday, you have time to spend in your hideout, doing crafting, trading, etc. And every night, you get to send one survivor to scavange, while you need to make your other survivors either rest, or protect your hideout from other scavengers. There are about a dozen or more different locations to explore, many 'events' to deal with, a weather system (you need to heat in the winter!), and more.  I would agree with some reviews here that, when you have completed the game, there is not much replay value, in the sense that you are just going to go through the same things, but with different characters. But if you buy the game, have no fear, you will get more than enough for your money. The music, gameplay and graphic style are all wonderfully balanced to make it interesting, depressing, scary, and everything to make you feel you are, really, just a survivor trying to live through this war of yours.

Pre-Game:  Friend: Hey, is that This War of Mine?  Guy: Yeah.  Friend: I've played it. It's supposed to be really depressing, but it never really got to me.  Me: I've heard about it. It's supposed to be a really good game. -Thinks about it for another month- Ok, I think I'll give it a try.  Day 1: Huh, this isn't so bad. These guys seem to have a pretty good shelter. Looks easy.  Night 1: Ok, this is interesting. I wonder what happens if you have no guards. -Sneaks carefully around the old burning cottage-  Day 2: Builds stuff, including a bed.  Day 3: -Gets robbed- God dangit. -Restarts-  Day 1: -Plays more strategically and starts putting guards up-  Day 7: -Katia moves in-  Night 10: Katia gets chased away by the armed guy at the old apartment.  Night 11: Katia empties the school of stuff and kills two homeless guys for a bag of canned food.  Day 11: Actually felt bad.  Night 15: Robs the elderly couple. Drops the meds out of guilt when the man says, 'Please, don't take my wife's meds. She's sick!'  Night 17: Katia finally gets over night 9. Marko gets out of a shootout with the apartment guy with a sliver of health.  Day 18-25: The three guys start getting injured because I didn't bandage them when they were slightly injured and Katia has to provide for all of them.  Day 20: Can't figure out how to make alcohol for bandages and can't find any wood for building heaters.  Day 23: Winter completely sets in. 2 Lethally wounded guys. Desperately need meds, nothing to trade for them.  Day 25: Katia dies from illness, Pavle died of injuries and Marko deserts.  Day 27: I still carry on with Bruno until I get him killed like an idiot while scavenging.  All this scavenging and I just barely had enough food for everyone.  After playing: -Thinks about the days of playing stuff like FarCry 3 and 4 and Civilization 5.-  I get the feeling I won't play for another month.

I picked up this game as a reccomendation from a friend, and I have to say that it is by far one of the best, story driven games that I have seen in a long time. Whenever a game about war breaks out, how it affects the civilian population is often completely overlooked. That is not the case here, and in fact, this game is entirely based on civilian survivors point of view.  Every decision you make will impact not only yourself, the other survivors with you, but any other survivor group alive in the story that you are playing. You will have to choose how to use your limited resources to best survive. Do I make a small animal trap, or board up another whole in my house to make it a little safer? Making the trap might seem like a good idea, giving you more food and all, but then suddenly, that very night, bandits raid your place and cause massive injury to those you left. All because you left that whole there and didn't put anyone on guard.   This game requires you to think outside of the norm, and consider things that you could only dream would ever happen to you.  10/10

OMG I haven't laughed so hard in ages. GET THIS GAME NOW!

Katia, Pavel, and Bruno were bunkered down in the city when the first shells arrived. Katia, a notorius writer, was getting stories to write for the news from local celebrities. While Pavel was an all star athlete- Bruno was a four star chef with his own show. None which mattered when government forces surrounded the city. They lived day to day, helping their neighbors as they helped them. Protecting the innocent from both rebel and military abusers. They even let in a defenseless woman live with them in her most dire time. They were Heroes in every way.   Until one day- Katia needed medicane for Bruno as he was uncoditionally ill with something the immune system couldn't fend off alone, and went to the auto repair shop to trade with a man living there. The man trading wanted more than we could offer, food, weapons, Jewelary. She knew it was the mans life or Bruno. So she rushed toward the man with her knife only to be shot before she could make the first slice. Her death brought suffering in Pavel who felt her death must be avenged. To make the man realize what he had done. The next night, he left bruno on his own to settle that score. With only 2 rounds and a hand gun he killed him but not to recieve one to his stomach as well. Bursting inside the shop, he sees a sick man, the father of the late trader and killer of your bestfriend. He too saw death. With everything he needed he limped back to home to give Bruno those meds he was in desperate need.   With Bruno doing better... Pavel bled out and died the next night. And the woman they protected and nurtured- gone. With their food and belongings taken with her. Bruno found his best friends cold corpse on the bed with Katias diary in his arms smothered in blood. He trembled on his cigarette and let it fall to the floor. Both were dead. And that was to much to bear for himself. With what little parts they had left, he assembled a noose as his final project, his final dish. He smokes his last cigarette and carved into beam that the rope was tied from, 'I'm sorry i couldn't return the favor'. Sobs fill the basement as shots are heard in the distance... The basement was silent- 3 days later the war had finally ended. RIP Katia Day 1-15, Pavel Day 1-16, Bruno Day 1-17.   This was my first 'story' and let me tell you. It was a story alright. A real depressing one and theres so many more you can embark in. 10/10 Video Games in its purist art form. A survival, a story teller, and an adventure.

This game is bleak. Unfathomably bleak.  Its bleak nature is primarily where it excels, allowing players to forge their own tales of pain and misfortune. Every single day is a huge struggle to survive with next to no supplies to work with, forcing you to make horrifyingly tough decisions.  This game will make you question your luxourious existence and will bring harrowing insight into the world of war.  10/10 would kill homeless people for food again

This game is something I'd recommend to anyone who is looking for a game that can leave an impact.  I cannot play this game for too long, usually one in game day, before I have to get up for a while because of the draining atmoshpere and desperate tone. In my opinion, if a game can make itself so heavy on the player but keeps them in, then it knows what it’s doing. Regrets, sympathy, despair. There's little happiness this game offers and it shouldn't, because that's how I imagine it'd be like in the character's place.  This game makes you weigh the costs and moralities of every action. But in the end it's less about the game and more how you handle these problems.  For me a lot of the experience was not rewarding, even when I achieved the small things I wanted to achieve, there was more to be done and there was always a consequence. I always felt the need to gain the unachievable well-being of of all my characters, and never did. What pushed me forward was the ambiguous ending of the war.  Overall, fantastic emotional experience that lies within the player and certainly leaves an impact. Wonderfully crafted style, narrative and tone. The most realistic war simulation I know.

A brutal war has come to the world of the Sims. There two types of gammers that wll enjoy This War of Mine;  1) Sims players who are sick to death of the Saccharin nature of The Sims but love the game play.  2) Survival fans looking for something different.   This War of Mine is a cold and brutal look at the cost of war, not from the point of view of the soldier but from the innocent bystander caught between two armies. Scrounging for food and materials takes up most of your time, everyone is cold and starving, and just when you think you are getting comfortable; you are raided by bandits and robbed blind. Back to the cold and hungry situation. You will be confronted sooner or later with choices that come down to either starving or robbing other innocent people of all they have to survive. And no matter what option you take, you will have to face the consequences of your actions. In this brutal war there are brutal choices.   There is little to no combat in this game, and rightly so. This is NOT war game, it is a hard scrabble survival game. If you are looking for a lighter FPS go ahead and skip this game, it is not ment for you. But if you are a fan of the survival story this may be what you have been waiting for.   Game play is similar to a platform shooter, point and click to cause your charicters to move from point to point. Actions take time and the interface is well set to allow multiple charicters to be busy at their own tasks at the same time. The graphics are well done but intentionaly washed out and depressing, don't expect amazing vistas or inspiring sites, this game is cold and dark.   Only a few hours into this game and I am looking forward to more. Rated 8/10  OK review revsion: Having played through the game once, much of my prior review stands. TWOM is a very good story and is probably one of the better indy games to come out in recent years. The story is compelling and the epiloge is actualy fairly moving. I am going to down grade my rating for one reason alone. The game is short. Far too short for a full price purchas, but when this game goes on sale make sure you get your self a copy.  Rated 7/8

A Dark Sim  For those of you who loved 'The Sims' and are enjoying the massively reproducing Survival genre, this could be your favorite game.  It is a side scrolling platformer-like game, but it feels more like a management UI, like Xcom's base, than most of the poor indie games coming out left and right. Everything you need and want to do is there. Side scrolling is sufficient.  PROS: Appropriate and well done soundtrack. Appealing graphics with interesting effects. Ability to do a campaign like game or create your own story.  CONS: Could probably be 10x more fun with small additions. Suspension of disbelief issue when you're starving, you steal some food from a hospital, then your entire team breaksdown in depression, causing them to starve or commit suicide. Your people have predefined personalities that don't change enough when desperation strikes. They would rather kill themselves than steal a can of tuna in some cases.  Recommended to people who are human. Or machine men that want to see what being human is like.

There have been a slurry of survival games, and most of them are (frankly) crap. Too easy, too predictable, too linear, too beta, there's a thousand things that can be wrong with a survival game. This game avoids those problems, as well as could be expected.   Resources aren't completely scarce, but they're used in large quantities, and even with ~20 of an item, you won't get a lot of use out of it. This feels just right, since I never felt comfortable with my situation, but I was also constantly crafting, building, and shifting priorities. Maybe i was flush for wood/materials, but I was out of food. Once I was good on food, I needed more materials to make water filters, or something like that. It felt difficult to survive, and that's what I want from a survival game.  Alongside food and rest, there's a 'emotion' value for each character, too. They become sad when they see atrocities, and will progress into depression and eventually become 'broken' and uncontrollable if you don't give them books, music, or other nice things to relieve the stress. I appreciated that in games like Don't Starve, and I appreciate it here, too.  The scripted encounters with NPCs are well done, with decent dialogue and enough ambiguity to keep you guessing what their real intentions were. The only problem with scripting these is that it's too easy to 'game' it after seeing the encounter. Your second, third, and subsequent playthroughs will feel less 'survival', and more 'metagame.' Other games (like FTL) solve this problem by randomizing outcomes, or adding other factors into the outcome of a dialogue choice, rather than just your choice (maybe your inventory, character being used to speak to the NPC, or location change the relative outcome of the encounter). But TWOM glues itself to rails. That's forgivable.  But let me level with you, the combat sucks. Unlike the rest of the game, there's no 'soft introduction' to combat. And that can be fine, if combat made any sense. You have to deliberately switch to 'combat mode', which entirely changes the environment actions you can use. Except that none of those actions are explained to you, and you have to spend a couple minutes examining icons and trying them out, hoping that you don't wind up making noise as you do.   You can never sneak up on enemies, their ESP goes off when you get closer than ~5ft to them - even if they're sleeping. And when you do, in fact, fight them, there's no feedback about how you're supposed to fight them. My first battle was a fistfight with someone whose house I'd broken into - but after madly clicking on the guy, the only thing i'd accomplished was my character sprinting in a circle around him. I tried to flee, but then my character inexplicably decided he couldn't go through the enemy, and wound up being lethally beaten. The next few combat scenarios ended up like this too, with the controls getting in the way, and lack of feedback failing to inform me *what* i was supposed to do. At one point i managed to knife a gunman to death, steal his pistol, and fire it at his compatriot. I was pretty sure that bullets, when they hit someone, were are pretty lethal thing. Unfortunately, they did less damage than punching him, and with one shotgun blast he killed my character.  This really wouldn't be so bad - every game has a learning curve. But when your character is dead forever, your other characters are stricken by grief (sometimes to the point of being suicidal or uncontrollable), and you need to *start a new game* to get back on track, that's a bad deal. It feels distinctly unfair to have the drop on an enemy, execute a well-planned ambush with the right weapon, at the right time, from the right angle, with no possibility of failure - and the game arbitrarily decides that it'll never work. Not just that it *randomly* won't work, but that your ambush *couldn't* work; it'll never work no matter how many times you try. And because you tried that entirely reasonable ambush, you now need to restart the whole game just to get back to where you were. That's frustrating.  Overall, play it. You'll like it. But just be aware that it has some player feedback and logic issues.

It's a good game, but everytime I play it I get depressed... If Steam allowed a number system, I'd give a 7/10. I unique and interesting concept nicely executed but bogged down by some conflicting mechanics and somewhat over stylization.  The concept is very interesting and fairly well executed considering there isn't much of a precedent for this kind of thing. A horror story told in the periphery of a war instead of in it. But if you are already here you already knew that, and you want to know if that interesting concept turned out any good.  Well, yes and no. While it did have some really strong moments all done entirely through game play, many times the 'game' part of it interfered with the mood it was trying to set. Keeping everyone feed and happy enough to keep going sometimes got tedious. And while the game works really hard to characterize each refugee with an individual story, thoughts and opinions, It just fell short of catching my sympathy and it made it really frustrating when their feelings conflicted with my own. There was frequently a tremendous difference between my motivations (succeeding at a game) and their's (surviving a war without losing their humanity). Other games have done this (Spec Ops: The Line specifically), but the opportunity was missed to make the dissonance between player and character poignant and it ended up just being frustrating. It certainly drove the point home that the average civilian really is not prepared for a war and the experiences it brings, but it hammers the point home a little too hard. The game worries so much about the player disconnecting that it grabs the playing by the shirt and says, 'AREN'T YOU PAYING ATTENTION!', and I found it making my slightly hostile to the point the game was trying to make.  If you are wondering if this game is worth your time and money it absolutely is. For all the over-empowering, testosterone driven, one man army and 'realistic' war games that have been made since the early days of gaming, it is worth remembering that wars really are quite horrible for everyone except those who do not directly interact with it in any way. As an Iraqi War veteran, I know what it's like when the public does not fully comprehend what it means to go to war, for the people who fight it or the people unfortunate enough to get caught by it. War is not hell, it's worse because it's real.. 'This War of Mine' is not perfect, but it is very much worth your time and support.

Day 1- A great scavenge, Tons of med's and food, best part I didn't even have to steal them- 'marko'  Day 3- Things are still looking great, some kids showed up asking for med's and we gave it to the- 'Marko'  Day 7- Things have taken a turn for the worse, we were raided and palve is ill, we shouldn't haven given the meds to the kids 'Marko'  Day 8- DANG IT! I just... I just had to, I... I killed a elderly couples son getting meds and food from the kitchen, as I left I heard them cry 'dear lord why' as they shouted his name- 'Marko'  Day 10-Well it was all for nothing.... Palve... he's dead I went back to the house to return the supplies I stole and see if I could help the couple, when I got there... I looked around and found them dead... I... I killed them'-Marko  Day 11- I.. I just can't take it anymore Why us??? - Marko   At night on Day 11 Marko slit his wrist and commited suicide.... I haven't played the game since... A simple but brutal game that does exactly what it sets out to do: makes the player think very, very hard about the choices they make to stay alive.   'This War of Mine' isn't exactly what I'd call 'fun,' but it's important, and it delivers its message well through mechanics, story, and visuals, which is my holy gaming trifecta. That said, I did appreciate the challenge of properly allocating resources and skills, and like all good sims the desire to make my environment 'better' got addictive pretty quickly.   What's impressed me most about 'This War of Mine' so far is how relentless it is. There's little in the way of combat, and the fighting you do encounter is more likely to make you feel powerless and angry rather than victorious, even if you win. Death carries significant weight in this game, whether it's the loss of a companion or the execution of a stranger over a cache of resources. Awful things happen randomly, and often enough they occur just when you can least afford them. You're constantly aware of the fact that you're barely scraping by, teetering on the edge of disaster. The goal of this game was to make you consider what it'd be like to live in a war zone, and it delivers admirably.

This game gets the best of me, no matter how hard you try, there will be a time that you'll have to do desperate things for your own survival, and the constant need of making the hard choices. If you like a game that's like The Walking Dead, I highly suggest that you get this game, it's highly emotional and it will make you feel good or bad, depending on the choices you've made.

I high recommend this game to people, great story and great gameplay. Happy Surviving!

THIS WAR OF MINE is a very impressive survival game with a twist. The art style is incredible and the uniqueness of the characters is a simple but effective twist. Characters change, seasons change, events change, locations change, items you spawn with changes, and the scenarios at those locations and what you find there also changes.  The replayability is huge and the scope for expansion is even greater. I don’t mind paying for DLC for a game that can give it new dimensions. New locations, new characters, alternative ‘home’ bases to start from, new craftables, even a new period setting are all something I’d love to see added. Scavenging with multiple characters and the ability to upgrade backpacks would also be a good addition.  WW1 would be particularly appropriate setting fleshed out with new characters, recognisable locations and real life events but maybe that’s scope for a sequel.  I’ve just about scratched the surface after 10 hours so I’m looking forward to seeing what the rest of the locations hold. Definitely a worth while purchase!

I really like this game. It's not too difficult, but there are some challenging aspects. Trying to play as a group without doing anything questionably moral is very difficult, but it is possible once you've successfully beaten the game once or twice. You could go through the game killing and stealing from everyone, but it'll affect various group members moods in a negative way to the point of suicide, in-fighting, or leaving. You have to find a balance and take these risks when foresight dictates this necessary. Anyways, interesting game to play for a few afternoons. I would look forward to a sequel that had much more of this and some new stuff.

This game is pretty good for all the reasons those countless reviews have mentioned. Which is why I will focus entirely on the negatives:  I don't see too much replay value. At its core it's a resource management / worker placement game with brilliant visuals and storylines. In my third try I figured out how to beat the game. The last 20 days were more than boring as an effect. Once you got a functioning supply chain running, there's nothing compelling you to risk anything. I got the house boarded up completely, 1 rifle, 2 guns, 2 rainwater collectors, 1 veggie garden, 2 rat traps, a distillery, herbal workshop and so on. Basically I could produce all the food I need, bandages, alcohol... I was self-sufficient. The rest was a lot of skipping days.  Summary: Get it on a sale, it's worth your money and time. You'll probably get 20-40 hours of fun and enlightenment out of it. It's beatiful while it lasts. Just don't expect too much depth and longevity. 7.5/10

I can't recall when I heard about this game. But I'm glad I made the purchase. As you've no doubt read elsewhere it's a different sort of war game, meant to mimic the experience of the vast majority of people who 'experience' war. The game play itself is straightforward and challenging. It truly is haunting. I've thought about actions I took in the game days later.  The visual style and music add to the harrowing ambiance.  Highly recommended.  My only quip is that it would have been good to have more random locations to visit in subsequent games (e.g. 50% core locations for each playthrough and then a large # of ones that might appear and might not). But this is a minor complaint.  I hope you survive.

If you love base building, resource management, and emotional breakdowns, this DEFINITELY game is for you. Surviving in the town of Porogen is a heart wrenching experience, making the player choose between committing some truly horrid acts and surviving. Will you rob that elderly couple, knowing that without their food and their meds your friends will die? Or will you attempt to risk your life to rob from bandits, who are fully armed and will shoot on sight? Choose wisely. 10/10 would cry again.

Absolutely amazing.  Really makes you think about how far you are willing to go to survive. I tried the nice way, taking only what nobody else claimed, that didnt work for long. Constant bandit attacks left my people despressed, wounded, and without food. On day 15 it all fell apart: No food to cook and no supplies to make weapons or tools, everybody is broken or depressed. That night I can only keep my people inside. We are attacked once more, Boris dies of his wounds, Pavle starves to death, and Bruno leaves never to return. Katia is the only one left. On day 16 I am able to trade for some bandages and a little food, just enough to make it to that night. That night is my last chance to survive, I need food. I go to the home of a couple unwilling to trade, my only option is to steal. I make it halfway through the house when I see the wife run upstairs to get her husband saying that there is an intruder, 15 seconds later he comes running and immediately attacks me. I am able to defend myself until he surrenders, he's just barely alive, I stab him one more time to finish it. There can be no failure on my part tonight. The wife rushes towards me, I'm thinking she is going to attack me for killing her husband. She collapses at my feet over his dead body and begins sobbing, I finish my looting listening to her cry. I return the next morning to find that I have been robbed again, this time they took everything, that coupled with the events of taking my first life leave Katia broken and unable to continue. That night she kills herself. She had survived 17 days.

Holy  SWEET JESUS This game is hard, but not only hard-in-game, but in the feels.
