Great concept and execution but this game is not for everyone. If you are looking for easy and entertaining gameplay - this game is not for you. If you are patient and willing to learn on your own mistakes, find out whe civilians in places like Sarayevo might have to cope with, learn to prioritize - this game is for you. Some people may find it boring and stop playing after they die couple of times but some, like myself, will keep trying again. This game is quite difficult and you can't choose the difficulty level. There is no tutorial other than try and error. It requires alot of thinking and decicion making. Supplies that can be scavanged are scarce and when all are gone you must either make them, steal or barter.   Pros: + original concept + minimalistic climate + interesting characters +clearly alot of research done on civilians surviving in cities under siege  Cons: - made me stop playing WoT for a while... - pricey for what it delivers in terms of graphics and other tech stuff, even soundtrack is near non-existant. It is only my opinion but I have willingly paid for it in hope it will help the devs stay on the market and hopefuly provide extensions and updates (free of charge) at least for a while. I wish them luck on the gaming market and beg they will never offer free to play titles.

Pros: On the flip side, I kind of liked the fact that you couldn't save the game. I enjoyed the challenge. We were running out of food, everyone was exhausted, we were dying of sickness. The man who comes to our door to 'trade' was trying to rob us blind, I had no choice. I had to break in to the apartment across the way. I knew there were people that lived there, but we were dying. I figured I could just slip in and out, hit the basement or something. Anything to just get something to keep us alive.   To my surprise, I was able to get in easily and everything worked smoothly until I tried to leave. Thats when he saw me, and he lifted his gun from surprise and fear, and I lunged at him before he could shoot. I will never forget his face, it has always haunted me.   Without hesitating I drove my knife into his chest. He gurgled a yell and hit the floor. Oh god. What happened? I ran for the door as fast as I could. Behind me I could hear them screaming. A woman yelled 'honey, please wake up!' I had taken their family away. For what? Some vegetables? I fell to my knees and cried. Then I walked. But no matter how far I walked, the journey for me back home would never happen, because I died inside that night.  I became broken. My brother had to journey out for me after that, I couldn't bring myself to even get out of bed anymore. That's how they got him. Knowing that the sniper's bullet was meant for me, that was my last straw. Now I'm the only one left, a fitting fate for me to watch you all pass on first. But I can't wait any longer, I'm coming to see you.   I hope you all forgive me.  10/10 Would have my soul broken again

Wow. This game is simply amazing. I plunged in the story, as if I was a war survivalist myself. This War of Mine is cleary a new kind of game you must try. AAA

Boris was our rock. On his strong shoulders he carried the wood and supplies that brought us through the long winter. His axe was patient, waiting in dark doorways for bandits and armed criminals. The business of murder made his heart heavy, even when it was needed to survive, but he always had you, Zlata. You always brought him back to us. Even after he killed those women (He killed them all! Only one was armed! He did not realize!) and was lost in despair, you helped him find the courage to go on.  But now he is dead anyway. One unquiet step. Too many soldiers, too many guns. He killed three, but what can one man do against seven?  It falls to you now, Zlata. The others are unsuitable. I know in your diary you wished for revenge. So tonight, you will step out of the safehouse for the first time. You will make your way to the military base. You will pull the axe from his body, still wet with soldier blood. You will creep in doorways and continue his work. And we will survive this war.  ---  BUT THEN the war ended and I didn't get the chance to corrupt Zlata into the hardened murderer I knew she could be. Bummer.

What can i say about this game ?  Out of the ordinary game, gives you a different prospective  of what war really is   You can choose to be ruthless or try to have some decency in your struggle for survival  A very strong anti-war game that keeps your mind and your consience busy  A definite must-have

You play a group of persons with different background stories and abilities trying to survive the war. That's it ... basically. You will try to stay alive and look for food, medicine, cigarettes and so on. It will feel like a grind without end in sight. And that's what the developers try to show you. You will have to decide, whether you will take the honest path and share with the other survivors or if you choose to kill for your basic human instincts.  Your characters will react to their actions. A murdering scavenger killing innocent people for food will get depressed and may commit suicide.   Another problem is that the game tries to be very unspecific, it doesn't name a specific location for the war, takes ordinary people as characters, has no voice-over and gives no backgroundstory on anything. It's basically 'You are a normal person. There is war. Survive.' And don't get me wrong, I know that this is used to show that war can hit anyone, but it makes the characters and dialogues/monologues seem very flat and unauthentic.  Maybe the developers can give the characters and monologues/dialogues a bit more depth while still keeping the aspect of showing that war can hit anyone.  All in all, I like this game for being unique and carrying an awesome message: ♥♥♥♥ THE WAR

This game can get very frustrating, mostly because you can't save your progress, and autosaves are not when you want them to be. That being said, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game, and my advice is to play through it and try to get entertainment out of your mistakes, because you can't undo them and that's what this game is supposed to be about: a realistic simulation of survival in war times. In other words, I'm trying not to blame the game for me being spoiled by other games allowing me to load previous save points so often.   One thing I really like about the game is that each play through will be different. As for the gameplay, it kind of feels like a combination of the theme of The Walking Dead and mechanics of Craft the World.

This game really struck a chord. The presentation is bleak and beautifully drawn like a moving pencil sketch. The characters have equally sketch-like back stories, simple yet impactful. The gameplay is engaging without the need for complex mechanics, but very challenging in terms of resource management. A feeling of desperation is there from the beginning and builds as the stakes rise.   Most of all the situation just feels incredibly real. The game lets us see through the husk of a house to show us the saddest side of war and how fragile life can become for civilians. The oppressive atmosphere makes moments of tenderness (such as a character comforting a fellow survivor who is breaking down) and brave decisions (such as giving up some resources to help a neighbour in need) stand out in the darkness. The grave consequences of errors of judgement make one feel sickeningly responsible.   + Wonderful presentation including visual style and music + Atmospheric and suspenseful + Challenging yet reasonable difficulty + Powerful message + Some replayability due to randomness of characters  - Some may not enjoy the bleak nature of the content - I wanted to hear more from the characters (the survivors)
i love this game. great game!

I've bought this game since the game was released at late Nov 2014. I personally considered one of the most realisitic survival pioneers out there. On the other hand, if you hurt yourself by fending someone getting robbed/♥♥♥♥♥. Yes, there was such a scene. Even though you gained practically nothing, you boosted the morale of your friends and yourself.   All these scenarios helped lead to the ultimate outcome at the end of the story. I'm not going to lie, this game WILL give you the feels. I'll have to give you an example;  I created a custom character, Aleksi. Aleksi, was made with my photograph, so naturally I tried to keep him alive as long as I possibly could. Entering the game for the first time, Aleksi, Emilia and Bruno were attempting to brave the horrors of war... and failed.  The downward spiral started after Aleksi came back from scavenging, and Emilia had become slightly ill. I thought that we would be fine, as I had the meds to keep her in one piece. However, the next night, Bruno got sick too. Extremely sick. I started to trade away food for meds. My people were getting hungry, and I had to chop up the bed to give wood to the trader for food. After getting 3 cans worth of food, Bruno was the only one in any shape to go scavenge.  He was shot dead for no reason by an unknown number of women in an apartment building. All he had on his person was a couple of planks of wood.  Emilia got sicker and sicker, and I sent Aleksi to the same apartment building with a shotgun, out of blind frustration and hatred at how far I had come, only for it to be dashed in front of my eyes. After killing the one with the shotgun, Aleksi hid in the shadows to ambush the others. When her friends came, they all broke down over her body, and reminisced to times long ago. I realized how horrible what I had done was; this wasn't some random death in a videogame, without moral repercussions. I murdered someone, and albeit they did it first, that's not an excuse to be like them.  When I tried to have Aleksi run away, another one pulled a gun. After being shot twice with a handgun or something, Aleksi butchered all of them with his shotgun. I got meds, and food, enough to keep everyone alive until the ceasefire, as I only had four more days left.  Emilia fell victim to the sickness.  I only just managed to bandage up Aleksi enough to keep him from bleeding out.  Over the next days, he fell into the status 'Broken', and promptly committed suicide.  TL;DR  This game made me cry at my own actions. I cried. Why I keep playing is a mystery to myself, I am ♥♥♥♥♥♥ my soul.  9.6/10

I have played many first-person shooters in my time, lots of war-based games, and i have enjoyed the killing, and the high-scores. This game completely reverses that.  Can something that can make you feel such sadness, that makes you really feel the consequences of your decisions rightly be called a game? I dont really feel so much like i am 'playing' when i play this game, there is way too much drama and humanity in it.   I have a few friends that lived as civilians in a war-torn country, and have been horrified at the stories they have told me. This game makes me feel like i have tasted that a little (even though i am in a nice warm house in a comfortable chair) The fact that there are millions of people right now actually living their lives like this right now is a horrible thought.  My only complaint is this game has not won enough awards (and it has won quite a few)  Get this game, Dont wait till its on special, just buy it now. It's a unique experience.

This game will play with your emotions, and I am not kidding when I say that I nearly cried on my first playthrough. I starded off fairly well, had some trouble with raiders, but got by. About eleven days in, I sent Marko to scavenge a church and he was killed when I sent him near a bandit. From there, the remaining three spiralled down to sadness, then depression, and then they either died or left. At thirty days, Bruno, the last one there, commited suicide. I was almost in tears. That is the second time a game has saddened me to the point of crying.   Its reliance on interractions and morals both good and bad, and stealth make for great mechanics. The use of bios, addictions, radios and other luxuries, and journal entries add an atmosphere that some games just can't implement.  The game still has its fair share of flaws, though. Ending the day before six-thirty pm means you miss chances to trade or assist people, which essentially means you just lost free supplies, or you pushed your survivors closer to suicide. If you go to scavenge, paranoia will make that rat upstairs into an agressive bandit, and while I appreciate that attempt to make you cautious, a two pound rat is much quieter than a two-hundred pound man who is also armed to the teeth (movement is indicated with red blips, and all the blips are the same size, btw).   I would honsetly rate it a 9.4/10 altogether, the gameplay is tedious, but never agitating, it portrays what it intends to portray, and is an emotional rollercoaster from start to finish. If you want a game that is also an interactive expirience where your decisions actually do affect gameplay, this is your kind of game.  (Sorry about the essay)

A great survival game that captures the atmosphere of a world that is based on survival and teamwork. The game allows the player to make choices not primarily based on negative consequences but more on morals and ethics.

I dont write reviews often, so when I write this, it means that I truly loved this game in every aspect. There is nothing i dont like about this game. It is almost perfect as it is. The script, and the movement. The only thing I would change is, the more bad things you choose to do, the more your characters get used to it. So you dont have the depressed emotion all the time.  The fact that you do grow attached to each character as you play, you dont want to do anything risky, so you try to decide the worth of your characters life, and the actions you are about to perform.  I was honestly scared to play this game because I didnt want my characters to die. And when i played the game, I weighed the options like the characters were my kids. I will highly recommend this game to everyone I see. Especially ones who think war it glamorous. Because, as this game shows, This War of Mine is not glamorous.

This game has quickly risen to one of my all-time favorite video games. I ended up clocking in 12 hours in one weekend once I started the game. The atmosphere is intence and affects you almost immediately; you feel the weight and depression that comes with the war atmosphere. The gameplay is simple and stream-lined. Overall, the game is genuinely addicting and fun to play.   The main downside is that there is a bit of a learning curve with the game. The first couple of playthroughs were incredibly difficult and I could not figure out get through 15 nights, let alon the whole war! But after some trial-and-error and help from the internet, I was able to figure out how to play, the best strategy, etc. Pro tip: If you are having trouble with the set storymodes, just create your own story/game mode with the survivors you think are best, adjust the war settings, etc. That was the best way to get over the learning curve and become comfortable with the gameplay. After that, I felt like I could handle any of the other story modes.   Finally, the story and background is interesting, but I wish there was more! You never get a full story about the war, why it started, or in-depth details about the world outside. Any information you get is through short clips from the radio, clues found across the locations, and some comments from the survivors themselves. Honestly, this just adds to the experience! It drives home the point that war is just universally pointless and awful; it does not really matter how the war started or who is in the 'right' because it is innocent people who suffer. I do wish there was more meat behind the characters: The diary entries are nice, but a lot of the characters just come off bland and forgettable. I would love if there were more diary entries that shared individual character experiences and thoughts so that they were more fleshed out. But that is just a nit-picky issue for a game that is really great.  Ultimately, this game is wonderful experience that makes you want to put so many hours into it without realizing it. I recommend it to anyone who is looking for a unique, emotional game that is sure to affect you on so many levels.

A game that allows you to observe the lives of civilians trapped within an armed conflict. You are placed in charge of a small group of refugees and must keep them fed, healthy and happy (as happy as you can be when facing the possibility of death). As the game moves on and supplies become more and more scarce, you are forced to make decisions that will make you question whether or not it was ethical choice. Will you devolve into the bandits? Killing and stealing supplies from 'innocent' people to keep you and yours alive? Or will you keep your humanity even if it means you go without? These are some of the questions you are forced to confront and ponder as you play this game.

Gameplay: 6/10 (gets repetitive with time) Atmosphere: 10/10 Graphics: 7/10 Overview: 8/10  Despair, sadness, anxiety, hunger, cold, and fear… I’ve expected those from a game that brings such a different side of a war story — the civil one. Yet it’s still managed to surprise me and overwhelm me with its heavy, dark, and truly hopeless atmosphere. With the feelings, the decisions. The choices.  The elder couple was defenseless and really needed that food — but „we” were starving. It was wrong to rob the hospital — but one of us was about to die without medicine. Killing a man was wrong — but he attacked.  The war in „This War of Mine” seems almost too real. It will make you feel truly thankful for every day those four people of yours manage to get through. For every hot meal, for every little precious item retrieved searching the city ruins, and every scrap of bandages bought with all that you’ve gathered. For every night without fighting off looters. And in the end it will make you feel like you’ve won this war. The real war.  Of course, if you survive.

This War of Mine is one of a kind. It's a real emotional rollercoaster. First you get into it by playing as you would normally do with others. You collect and build stuff. You get tools and weapons. Pretty soon you realize this is a lot harder to achieve. Your characters get exhausted, depressed, wounded, killed. It's not going all that well for them. A single cigarette or a bit of music will bring joy to their small refuge. They will meet other people in their bleak world. These encounters are usually not that pleasant. They'll try to shoot you, and for good reason as you probably sneaked into their house intending to rob them of their much needed supplies. It's survive or die out there, and sometimes you get to help someone - an event when I actually felt good for these small victories. You must deal with the consequences of your choices. Someone's going to die eventually. Thread carefuly. Life is fragile. It's not something that you usually get to experience with other games out there. This one will. Forget about buffing your character, building a badass tank/assassin/mage. Forget about ego-trips. This War of Mine hits you where it hurts, and for good reason. Treat yourself. But be careful. 10/10

I normally do not get side scrolling games. I did that in my youth playing NES games like Contra and Castlvania. 'This War of Mine' catch my eye for its visual artwork and story. Your characters are placed against nearly impossible odds: survive life as a civilian in a war torn city. You are given a collection of individuals that have their own distinctive abilities and emotional levels. Some are the good people, and others just have no emotions (the war removed them?).   Each day is broken into two phrases: Day and Night. During the day, your chracters try to eat food, drink water, make repairs on the house and other tasks. At night, one of them goes out to scavange anything you can find. Danger lurks around every area. Making the wrong decision can be very costly. As the game unfolds, you learn more about each character's past and how they came to be in this spot and time. In all the gloom and dreary, its a fantastic game to play through. There is even a cooperative board game being produced of this game (for 1-6 players) on Kickstarter.

This is a great looking and very atmospheric 2D game. You control a group of survivor in a war-torn city. It has many of the tropes of the genre: send out survivors on scavenging missions, search for items to bring back, craft/upgrade tools, weapons and facilities, protect your base, defend against attacks, get your survivors to feed/heal/rest. However, the originality is in the setting and the tone. When you take food away from a ruined building, you get the sense that this was somebody else's stash and that they will suffer or die because of it. You are tempted to do terrible things in order to survive. When somebody comes knocking for help, you are torn about whether you should sacrifice your hard earned items or shut them out. You are filled with the hopelessness of the situation and you never feel it's a game that can be won in the conventional sense.

War has never been so much fun... Or is it? First you try to keep those ungrateful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of your team alive through war. You'll do everything. Rob robbers by sneaking or killing, rob innocents and hospitals. You collect trash from derelict places for supplies. Eat anything. Anything.  If you don't starve to death, die by illness, freeze to death, die by wounds inflicted by continuous assaults to your house, sniper fire, too risky salvaging trip or your team fighting eachother then... Well... Then they probably will be sad, depressed or broken. Or they abandon your team and steal it's possessions on their way. Or lay in hangover, weeping and crying. From day to day.  Places vary from game to game : loot you find, characters you meet, dangers you are pitted against. You never know what to take with you when going to raid after supplies. Weapon - knife, axe or gun. Or makeshift tool like shovel or crowbar to go past obstacles - be them concrete, wood or flesh and bones. Or saw and lockpick for grates and locks. Or items to barter with some not-so-hostile NPC's. Ofcourse you can kill them or steal from them. If your character can live with his actions. Whatever you take with you takes space from loot you're able to carry back so it's better to choose well.  It's all about suffering and pain from the hopeless start to the very unhappy ending. Because you know, there's no happy endings in war, only choices to make, survival or death. Little meaningless people trying to struggle through hell. Alone. Suffering. Depressing? Oh yeah! Fun? Not really. Interesting? Definitely. Enjoyable? In it's own masochistic way.  It is possible to achieve different kind of endings to the story. Not to just survive but achieve characters own personal goals. It is possible to do few single heroic acts. Odds are always against you. So be ready to enjoy your victories with grain of salt.  If your character dies it is permanent for that playthrough. This makes both wins and failures feel like personal wins or losses. You will be genuinely happy if you do well. And it will really ♥♥♥♥ you off when you fail. Ragequit is not a remote possibility.  This game makes you think about what you value most. In the end, if you manage to do one or two unselfish 'humane' decisions and still survive... Even that feels good. Characters do have personality : some of them you like, others you tolerate. Or not. Even NPC's are well scripted. Most of them feel like believable characters. To hear them talking about atrocities, crimes they are going to do, about their miserable lives, their kills... Oh boy. Best and worst of mankind. You will hate those heartless murderers even when you see some of their point of view. And the price you pay for your little piece of heaven. Or bread. It will cost you. LOT.  Most important thing about this game though : it really makes you value your own life, everything you have. From food and water to warmth of home and friends. And it makes you value peace.  There's shot down wall in the game with graffiti that summarizes it all.  F*** The War.

It's very good. The storytelling and unforgiving world are phenomenal. I really enjoy it.   The pathfinding is almost gamebreaking, however. In a game with permadeath and nearly one-hit kills, you can't have a point and click navigation system. And if you do, you certainly can't have poor pathfinding. I've lost too many survivors to frustratingly stupid pathfinding that walks my survivors right into the barrel of a bandit when there was a safer way.

I saw this game and it went instantly onto my wishlist. Before I could even consider buying it for myself on pay day, it was gifted to me by my stepfather, who had thought 'Oh, this looks kinda neat.' He didn't even notice it was on my list.  Now, we haven't had the same taste in games for a long, long while, but we both agreed on the potential of this game to be engaging and addictive. If I had only known how, I probably would have re-gifted to a friend.  My first three days of ownership were spent glued to the screen, trying to make every scrap of food last, keeping the shelter warm through the winter, and praying for enough ammunition to hold off the increasingly-frequent bandit raids with the one handgun I had managed to salvage. I checked the radio religiously every day, making sure to scan all stations every time, for news from outside the city. I was doing everything I could to make it, and was doing well, despite the trials.  Then, it all fell apart.  As I was preparing to log out after my third bingning session, I noticed that Paval had gotten ill. Nothing major, but we had no medicine and nothing to trade away to get more. Boris was injured after a bandit attack and couldn't go out when night came. Everyone else was exhausted with fatigue and hunger. I made a tough call and decided to play a little longer, so that I could take care of the situation before logging in and getting caught-up in something unrelated where the sniffles would turn deadly.  Paval, feverish and unwell but otherwise functional, was sent out to scavenge. The only place with medicine that hadn't been raided was a warehouse overrun with rebel fighters who were not at all happy about me showing up the last time. Shots had been fired but wounds had long since mended and a bit of valuable loot was taken away in the process. This time, there was no way I could manage.  Time for the tough call in-game. I glanced to my girlfriend, sleeping a few feet away, and knew that I was going to catch hell about staying up so late and waking her as I crawled into bed. I knew it was going to suck and I'd feel like crap but, hey, I was about to have that in real life, so why not go for the full monty?  The house at the edge of town had an old couple living in it alone. They'd managed to avoid the worst of the war's problems and somehow still had everything intact. I snuck in, crept upstairs, and managed to steal some medicine from the bedroom. I began back down when the old man caught me on the stairs. Busted. It was either fight or flee and I'd already stolen from these poor folks, so I wasn't about to sucker punch the geezer. I was about to bolt when he said something that haunted me (and my characters) for days afterwards: 'Please, don't hurt us! Take anything you want, just leave my wife's medicine! She's very ill.'  I kicked myself. How had I not thought of that? These people were old, alone, and afraid. Even if their house wasn't bombed and armed soldiers weren't snatching their supplies by force, they were victims as well. When you walk into a situation without learning about the people involved, you might make a blunder that could cost someone their livelihood, their wealth, or their life. I needed the medicine, though, and they'd talked about family nearby while I was upstairs, rummaging through their cabinets. They'd be okay. I grabbed a cigarette and some spare parts to trade and then ran with the medicine.  I got home, made sure Paval took the valuable medication for his runny nose to prevent it from getting worse, then logged out with the survivors of this hell all kicking themselves and blamaing Paval for being selfish. I felt just as rotten as he did. He was depressed for days and only became functional after a bottle of vodka. Which is to say that he snapped out of his funk long enough to start a fight with Boris and get them both hurt.  I was such a fool, but my little band was alive. The winter was almost over and, just as the weather began to get better, an unexpected knock at the door made my heart sink: the children I'd been unable to help earlier with extra food (all of my characters were starving) pleaded and begged for medicine for their sick mother. I'd been unable to help them every time they arrived and asked for even the simplest things.  Paval's depression worsened. Boris became a sad sack of human flesh laying in bed all day and rising only to eat. Everyone fell into such a horrible miasma of bad feelings and grudge-holding that tempers flared nightly. Between the bickering and fighting and bandits and armed soldiers, it was too much. Boris died of wounds suffered when a fight got out of hand. Paval, weakened by weariness, a new illness, his injuries, and depression, died in a fight with a knife-wielding man in a bombed-out school over a pair of old books and a cigarette. The other two starved to death in the basement while Paval was out trying to save them.  I have never become so attached to a character in any game as I have to those people in This War of Mine. The next playthrough saw Boris saving a young woman from a would-be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soldier with an assault rifle inside a grocery store by choking him to the ground from behind with a shovel and then caving his skull. The others lauded him as a hero and I felt somehow redeemed from my actions in the previous playthrough. I wept with joy and cheered in triumph alongside these pixellated human beings. I suffered their grief and outrage at every setback and mistake. I mourned the passing of every one of them.  This was not a game, I decided; this was an experience.  I had to stop playing. HAD TO stop. I was spending as much time trying to just survive another day in this war-torn hell as I was at my job. I intend to return, though. Once I have enough vacation time and a girlfriend who won't make me sleep on the couch for trying to save a (virtual) life, I will return to the city and do what I can to help the survivors get by.  Until then, I will be content to sit back and remember the time I spent not playing a game, but experiencing the emotional roller coaster of my life.  1,000 / 10 Would feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for weeks again.

Last night.... Marko killed 3 men. First one with a shovel to acquire a shotgun with a few rounds. after slaughtering the other two men in the building he went home and was never the same man. He broke down in a deep depression. The harshness broke his will to eat, drink, or even live. This War of Mine is inescapable. Survival is nearly unfathomable. Only the strongest will survive the creulity of each day.   To this point I have made it as far to day 17 before all of my people were killed or mentally and physically broken.

This game is quite unique, instead of being a super soldier and completing missions. Your a realistically vulnerable human being. It really does feel like being in a war. Its a real eye opener to people who don't understand what its truly like being in a war. The challenges of survival the regret of varrying choices you made to do just that, survive. Its pretty hard intense I would even say it seems impossible at times, but that is what its like in a real war, hard. I would recommend this game to anyone seeking either a realistic game a challenging game or an original game, by the way no difficulty settings. Its hard by default so if you seek an easy going casual game look away from this.

This was a wonderful game, and I'd love to put even more time into it. It's addictive, depressing and fun in ways most games don't engage. It uses its mechanics perfectly to express the total chaos and confusion civillians feel during wartimes. The lack of any tutorials might be a bit annoying at first, but soon you realize that it enforces the game's message - no one expects to be in a war, and no one is truly ready for it. The confusion of what to do adds to the engagement of the game, rather than make it unfun.  I do, however, have a problem with the game's setting. This war of mine offers a fresh take on the survivalist genre, but it's not neccesarily a step in the right direction. The setting of war rather than, say, a zombie apocalypse proved to be a good setting and helped dramaticize the game and the decisions you make in it. However, it simply gives a false look at how wars turn out, or how people live through wars. For a game that's main message is the horrors of war, it simply does not give the most honest answer. It took the most extreme cases around, and turned them into the norm in this game.  That being said, the game is still excellent, having a stellar soundtrack and great visuals. The mechanics are well enforced, and I can still easily recommend this game for anyone. I wouldn't necessarily buy it if I were you, but lend it from a friend or something. It's a great experience, but a short one.

I rarely write reviews, but I HAD TO come and express my love for this game. I have NEVER loved a game as much as i do 'This war of mine'. Its a wonderful piece of art, you are taken deep in to the game from the very beginning, i love this game so so much that im finding it hard to express my feelings towards it. Its the PERFECT game, this is THE game i have been waiting for all my life. I love survival games, and this does it so so so well that its hard to put in to words. You gotta play it to understand what i mean. If you like survival games, or if you like games in general then i recommend you buy this and play it. Im on Day 8 now, i only came out of the game to write this review, make a cup of tea and get back to it. On day 6 i went scavenging and one of my people was ill and we were short on food, i went to the home of 2 elderly people (man and wife) and murdered them in cold blood as they sat in front of the fire place eating supper. I took everything they had.. I had to do it for my people to survive. This in turn made my charachter depressed and on Day 7 an argument broke out between the 3 of us, we talked it over and all is fine now. We have enough food and medicine to last a few more days and i gathered enough wood to make 2 beds for us to sleep in. I also found a gun stashed in the garden at another house, how i found it was i read a note that was hidden in the cupboard at the house, and i dug up the weapon. Its gonna come in handy for night time as we have been raided a couple of times already, so we should now be able to defend ourself.  I dont think this game can be improved any more, i honestly dont. But i do have some suggestions on things to add. When i raided the house of the two old couple, i wondered how nice it would be for us to move from the shelter were at now in to this new home. Maybe you could introduce an option for us to change shelters? I know this is a long shot but i can see this game played online with other people. Maybe a coop version.. Dunno what else to say, you MUST buy this game NOWWWWWW

A brutal war has come to the world of the Sims. There two types of gammers that wll enjoy This War of Mine;  1) Sims players who are sick to death of the Saccharin nature of The Sims but love the game play.  2) Survival fans looking for something different.   This War of Mine is a cold and brutal look at the cost of war, not from the point of view of the soldier but from the innocent bystander caught between two armies. Scrounging for food and materials takes up most of your time, everyone is cold and starving, and just when you think you are getting comfortable; you are raided by bandits and robbed blind. Back to the cold and hungry situation. You will be confronted sooner or later with choices that come down to either starving or robbing other innocent people of all they have to survive. And no matter what option you take, you will have to face the consequences of your actions. In this brutal war there are brutal choices.   There is little to no combat in this game, and rightly so. This is NOT war game, it is a hard scrabble survival game. If you are looking for a lighter FPS go ahead and skip this game, it is not ment for you. But if you are a fan of the survival story this may be what you have been waiting for.   Game play is similar to a platform shooter, point and click to cause your charicters to move from point to point. Actions take time and the interface is well set to allow multiple charicters to be busy at their own tasks at the same time. The graphics are well done but intentionaly washed out and depressing, don't expect amazing vistas or inspiring sites, this game is cold and dark.   Only a few hours into this game and I am looking forward to more. Rated 8/10  OK review revsion: Having played through the game once, much of my prior review stands. TWOM is a very good story and is probably one of the better indy games to come out in recent years. The story is compelling and the epiloge is actualy fairly moving. I am going to down grade my rating for one reason alone. The game is short. Far too short for a full price purchas, but when this game goes on sale make sure you get your self a copy.  Rated 7/8

What I like most about this game is that each shot counts. If you are even slightly injured, that injury doesn't just go away by replenishing your HP, you have to bandage the wound and have that person rest so it can heal. Each death counts, if you kill someone else, it is a big deal, your characters become depressed and won't forget it. Even stealing can leave you feeling bad for those electronic characters.  This game can really draw you in if you let it. An example of what can happen, I sent Katia (one of the characters) to a supermarket, where she witnessed a soldier ♥♥♥♥ a woman. After that she went from the optimist of the group to depressed. Several days later I sent her to the bombed out school where she got caught looking through a homeless man's few possessions. The man attacked her, but she had a knife, and in self-defense she killed him. The next day she spiraled out of control and committed suicide.  About a week later a man named Anton stopped by. He was a mathematician before. Somehow he had been seriously wounded. I let him into my group, gave him my only bandage, and let him sleep on the bed. All my characters were sick, since it was the middle of winter at the time and I had no wood left and burned my last book, but I sent Arica to a military base with a bag full of moonshine and cigarettes to trade for food and medicine, she was shot dead. Several days later, after Anton had recovered, he stole all our supplies and left.  By the end of winter my original three survivors were no longer surviving, I was down to an older lady and a mechanic, both of whom joined my group late game. Every night raiders were successful at stealing from me, while my scavenging missions were less and less successful. I briefly considered restarting the game there, both of my characters were sick, one was wounded and all I had left were two coffee beans, a lock pick and some electrical parts, but I realized their story had to end, even if they all died. So I used that lock pick to open a dresser in a nice family's house where I found all their cans of food, components and medicine and I almost cried in real life, that was enough to get me by for the last several days.  Finally, around day 45, the war ended and I had two survivors. Then the game played a montage of every good and bad thing I had done. I was a little ashamed of some of the things I did, such as stealing from a defenseless old couple in the middle of winter.   Overall it was a great game, sure there was an occasional glitch and some game play aspects seemed clunky. But no game has ever gotten me so involved in the story as This War of Mine. I would definitely suggest it to anyone.

Fantastic, both as a game, and as an experience. I typically don't feel a lot of emotional engagment with games, but this one actually made me feel bad when I killed innocents, and constantly terrified for the safety of my survivors.  Even when I was clearly ahead of the curve I never felt like it became an auto win.  Quite polished too, I only encountered one possible bug around freezing to death (even though I was running two heaters) I say possible, because it could be I just didn't understand how to use the heaters properly. I later found you can add more than one piece of fuel, so that could be the thing.

Don't play this game like you play other games. The greatest advantage of it, is an atmosphere and the best This War of Mine experience, is granted when you are in trouble. Do your best to immerse yourself into the hellish fate of your survivors, it will be worth it. And above all, DO NOT ragequit. Do not start over as soon as things will get awry. They will one way or another, it is part of the game. This game is meant to shatter you, until you love it, when things finally get on plus, maybe even in the same playthrough, as when you lost Marko and his scavenging skills.  This War of Mine is won when the war is done, not when you some troops get at the roof of a random building and stick a flag at the top. It is like you hear from your scavanger at military outpost: 'I lost track of which side they are on'.

Yes I've only played 3.6 hours (At time of review) but holy hell...This game will change your perspective on everything.  On my first attempt, I lost one of my characters. I paused the game and stood away from my computer for a good 5 mins, just thinking abou where I went wrong.   2nd attempt (Which is still going at time of review) and I made it to day 9 without anything going wrong, but then that night, I went a little bit too far. My main scavenger was raiding a house with people in it, and I was trying to sneak past, but then I was spotted. One of them had a shotgun, and shot my scav, seveirly wounding him. I hid him in the basement, and let him rest. He couldn't get out. Then the person with the Shotty came down the ladder, and I clobbered her with my hatchet. The other two in the house were un-armed, but I killed them anyway. By the time I had gotten the shotgun, it was 20mins till dawn, and I wasn't getting out in time. He had arrived home that afternoon, but was leathaly wounded and broken. I had one of my guys talk him back into life, and give him some canned food. But...I had no bandages, and didn't have the means to make any. For three nights, I went Searching places for bandages. Even went to the hospital, but they wouldn't help. That night, my main scavenger died from his wounds.  I give this game a 9.5/10 on the feel raiting, and a 9/10 on the game itself.  ~Vri

A survival game, where you need to plan ahead of time what you will need to be getting during the exploration phase. Your resources are limited, time is precious, and you will be constantly be making decisions on what you will bring back to the shelter with your limited inventory space.  Wood ? Sure I'll take that we need a lot of it, wow heck it takes a lot of space.  Components ? Yes, I have to build a lot of stuff. Meds ? Oh yes, these fetch for a great reward when exchanged for basic components, and a cold comes faster than you might think. Food ? I don't have enough space now, we are a bit hungry, but I can come back tomorrow night for that, and starve myself a bit more. Weapon parts ? We were raided last night, we managed to fend those thieves off, but we will need at least a knife to keep them in their place the next day... Electric part ? I don't have enough space in my inventory right now, but we need to build that upgraded stove at all cost before winter freezes us to death... Books, cofee, cigarettes ? I don't have enough space in my inventory right now, but with the hunger, the sickness, we could all use some more comfort in those little things. Our cook got wounded last night when some pillagers tried to force their way in our shelter. The war front is blocking access to the hospital. He can hold himself alive by staying in bed, but we will need to find bandages fast, or learn cooking... Water ? I wish I had brought back every single drop of water when I could. All we can do now, in the middle of winter, is burn every last bit of wood and books we have to try and melt snow to get the water we need to cook some food.  A complete run lasts for about 8h, and the game cen be replayed with different set up in a really enticing way.  Once you know about the basics of the game and explored the scavenging areas available, this game is similar, but really much, much easier than 'don't starve'.

A fantastic blend of 2D stealth platforming and party-based survival with light crafting. This War of Mine provides an unequivocable view of war that no one can mistake, while still allowing the player choice in his decisions. A unique and striking visual aesthetics does not take away anything about from the intended message, which is said so succinctly in graffiti just outside the player's in-game home. Soundtrack is also very good.

This War of Mine is one of, if not, the best strategy games I've ever played. I was introduced to this game by a YouTube video. After watching a few episodes of the gameplay, I decided that I had to buy the game for myself. The different group of characters at the start of the game, and throughout the game as well, make this game one of the games I love to come back to. Each time you start a new game, you start a new experience. If you're on the rocks about this game, I suggest watching some videos on it, but nothing can compare to actually playing the game, and making decisions for yourself.

This War Of Mine takes a new approach to the 'post apoclipse' genre by, insted, making a game that feels real and impactful. You start out with three survivors, in my case I started with Pavel; a football player looking for his purpose in the tragity of war, Bruno; an overweight smoker but a damn good cook, and Katia; a young reporter with bargening skills. Katia was by far my favorite. Pavel was killed pretty early on by a group of militants, 'shot like a dog' to quote Bruno. But Bruno was't exactly the most likeable person himself. I distinctly remember him stealing from an old married couple, the wife was sick and the husband was too weak to fight back so Bruno just took from them. And he seemed to be the only person not bothered by this. Soon after the death of Pavel a new man arrived at the doorstep of my home looking for shelter, his name was Nicola, and of course we welcomed him into out home, and they lived happily in there own little house. It seemed somber and seprate from the war. And with nightly scavenging runs, food seemed to be in abundance.  But like all good things, this soon ended. On a supply run Katia was gathering supplies from an abandoned house, but as it happens it wasn't as vacent as she had originally thought. A young man burst though the door yelling: 'Get out of my F*****g house! I'll F*****g kill you!!!' as he shot Katia once. Katia ran for her life as the man continued to take shots, and she was hit once again before eventually escaping. This left her on the brink of death, and barely able to function, she was bandiged up and put to bed. But the house had supplies they need. So the next night Nicola went out to gather the rest of the supplies, and this time he did it with a knife. He not only found supplies though, he also found out that the yound man was surviving with his parents; an old couple no younger than 70. But he was inexperenced and was soon cought and meeting a similar fate as Katia, exept Nicola didn't get away. He was on the ground, at the feet and mercy of the young man with the shotgun. And the young man let him go.  'Just this once,' he said 'but if you ever come back, I will kill you.' Nicola's injeries were far worse than Katia's. And they were out of bandiges. Nicola died soon after. Enraged by his death, Katia decieded that she would deal with the pain of her wounds, and she would take everything from the bastrds that killed Nicola. But insted she ran into the young man's old father. He screamed for help and by instinct; Katia stabbed him twice. The young man and his mother didn't even fight back this time. They just sat at the old man's courpse and cried silently. Katia died the next day, from what no one was sure. Maybe it was from blood loss, maybe from the overdose of pills she took to end her own life. Either way, Katia was dead and nothing in hell was gonna bring her back.  Then Naomi came. She was a happy, upbeat musican that seemed to carry a good energy where she went. But it wasm't enough help Bruno. He became severly depressed, and insted of taking the easy way out like Katia, he took all the food they had and ran while Naomi was sleeping. Now Naomi lives alone, unable to find food, unable to stay warm, unable to heal from a wound she god defending from looters. She counts the days until eventually hunger, the cold, or even her own depression overtakes her.  This War Of Mine is not a game, it is an experence, and one that must be played. I have never felt so attached to anything other than my cat, then I was to these imaginary people that seemed to real, and personal and amazing. I wish you the best of luck.   But serously, PLAY THIS GAME!!!

Seems good so far. The game is for Sim lovers and micromanagers. I like the nightly scavange runs the best since I can choose to manage 1 character.   First impression is 8.5/10 -1 for the reason I thought this game was not point and click and no game pad control logic. -0.5 for the micromanaging aspect.

This war of mine was a fun moment. it cost me a night out, and gave me a few more in. It had a small amount of replayability but very small. I was waiting for an expansion but as the the original posters mentioned, and indeed the devs...This is it...thats all you are getting..so long and thanks for the fish... Dont reduce it to 1.99 sale .... stay loyal to the people that paid the price....Will come round and set fire to you whilst eating beans from a rusty can. Oh btw the guy and the kids are ... dead.... sorry but it was too cold to get out of bed and answer the door...Plus it's my medicine so bugger off

Its the Sims. With character devlopment. And the house you get is random. And in shambles. Its like the sims, but 100% more serious. In general I have a pretty cold heart when it comes to things like this; but stealing from old people didnt seem right....even as I did it. But hey. We gotta survive. I never went back to that place. It is for all purposes a game. But it felt real.  9/10, with the only actual nitpick being; its a bit complicated, and rightfully so. I'm proud to own this game, and it will give me much enjoyment for the years to come.

This War of Mine,  Is probably one of the best games I've played so far and quiet the eye opener in some situation. How far would you go to achieve your goal? Why and who would you help? What is the ultimate price to survive and would you stick to your friends until the bitter end?  Those are things that become a daily routine in this game. And instead of walking around as a soldier who might just shoot anything. You're anything a soldier might just shoot. But, the danger doesn't only come from the armed forces, but also from other survivors; even from within your own group.  You have to plan ahead, be prepared for anything and if needed take some hard measures to achieve your goal. In this game you're not a hero. You're just trying to survive in one way or the other.  So, but, how does this actually work? Well, you're basically bartering, helping (or not) and crafting throughout the day. During the night you go out to scavenge and manage other smaller, but very important tasks. (Not telling what exactly, but it's well done)  This goes on and on for as long as possible, but never gets dull. That is, if you're up for a game with a really very mature content.

Played about 15 hours. Very good game - but not amazing. Only lasted 25 days my first attempt but survived at 41 days my second try with everybody alive fed and content.   Pros -Original survival type game -Awesome atmosphere/art -Sense of struggle -Keeping characters happy based on their morals whilst keeping them warm/fed/well rested etc is challenging. -Stealth aspects of the game were really cool.  Cons -You need to wait for your character to do things - even if it's only a short wait, it kind of makes the game run at a slower pace.  -Kind of repetitive.  I would recommend it if you like survival/stealth games. It has potential to replay with different characters and create your own etc, but after 15 hours I've had enough. Maybe after a break I'll play some more.
great game be awesome if it was online gameplay

A short but fresh take on war themed games. War affects us all, how will the decisions you make affect others? This gritty melancolic game, while being pretty hard because everything you do has consequences and unforseen effects, shows you the sad reality that war affects us all in many ways. A beautiful artwork coupled with believable characters and interesting unfoldings make this management / adventure hybrid play itself out.

This game is really different. Which is a good thing! That being said, it may not be everybodys cup ot 'tea'. Takes some serious critical thinking skills and planning to play this game well. Has a pretty dark sense into it.
A very good game and touches the hart.
This game will ♥♥♥♥ your spirit, ♥♥♥♥ your feels, and destroy brain. 10/10 would starve again.
Very nice gameplay and atmosphere.
In 31 days of the war i led 5 people with a bright future to their deaths. I am now scuicidal.   7/10 not enough water

I found this game really beautiful and gripping. It shows us the true horrors of war and what people have to go through during these times. The game is also quite hard and requires a lot of planning and patience.  The Good Things: -Non-Linear Storyline. There are many different stories to pick (After you finish the first one) and many different scenarios to witness in the many different places you can visit. If you are angered by a soldier who is going to ♥♥♥♥ a woman you can change it's outcome!, If you are worried about some kids with a sick mother who is about to die you can change her fate! The survivors reveal their story over time and comment on actions of other survivors.  -Realistic Combat. Except for the bullets and stealth, the combat is very realistic. Players don't have more health over enemies (Unless you're playing as Boris or Roman), and killing is not always the option because some enemies will surrender.  -Realistic Simulation. There is no Easy, Normal, or Hard, there is only Realism. When the tempertures drop, people can get sick. When crime is on the rise, the group will suffer a lot of raids. When survivors are depressed, the group falls apart.  -Different ways to play. Players don't always have to steal food. They could trade for it or even grow their own. Players don't always have to use stealth kill enemies, with enough bullets and body armor they could rush in and shoot everyone.  -Beautiful Graphics. The graphics perfectly captures a war zone and contributes alot to the atmosphere. By the looks of it  the game seems to take place around eastern europe during the 1990s.  -Shows us what war really is. This game is a big ♥♥♥♥ you to people who support wars or even play the so called 'Game of the Year' Call of Duty or similar. It shows us that the Military will do anything for 'Glory' and will abuse their power for their own desires.  The Bad Things: -You are only able to have one save. It autosaves after every night and it prevents you from making backups saves or restarting a day incase you make a mistake.  -Food is extremely scarce and limited. There are only 4 types of food: Vegetables, Raw Meat, Canned Food, and Cooked Meals. There is no existance of Rice, Fish, Bread, or other foods which are commonly found in many places. Some places, like the Military Outpost, Have a lot of food but not enough to keep a group of 4 well fed for a week.  --Water is kind of useless. Nobody drinks water, only Coffee and Alcohol. Water is only used for in making Moonshine, and Cooking Food.  My Score for this game is: 9/10. Many of the bad things were not that bad but some tweaks should be implemented. Overall the game is really great for an Indie game and it's worth your money!
This game does a great job in testing your humanity.

This game does a very good job of setting the somber atmosphere of a war time survivor. Everything that once was has turned into a bleak forlorn present. You really feel like your there yourself. The scariest thing in this game is seeing another human that isn't in your party. The first play through is the best playthrough, since everything is so new to you and thus everything you do scares you since you don't know what will happen, and yes, death is a very real thing in this game.  9/10 I was on the edge of my seat the entire time I played.

While a good game, I honestly expected it to be more indepth and neuanced than it turned out to be. There really isn't any interaction between the survivors you control, kind of a missed opportunity. But hey, worth the money and your time if you're in the mood for something a little different than run and gun action games......oh wait, it does have running...and gunning.......just buy the damn thing!
Great game!

Great ambiance. Taking care of your home/base, planning for the night (who's guarding and who's gotta sleep), scavenge new locations, trading with bandits ... upgrade your home with what you found, feed your people if you can, heal and give medecine to your people if you can, heat the house if you can, melt some snow for water ... two kids are asking for medecine, there mom's dying... I can't spare any for the moment... ♥♥♥♥ this war... Great game though !

When you are confronted with the choice of doing the right thing or saving your own neck, what do you choose?  I've played a lot of survival based games and I've never felt bad for any of the immoral choices I tend to make to keep myself alive. In fact, I think its safe to say I usually make the immoral choice because 1) Its a video game and 2) In a lot of games, the immoral choice is often highly rewarded. This is not always the case in 'This War of Mine'. Every decision you make (good or bad) has the potential to bring absolute disaster to you and the rewards are usually no more then a scrap of food, a bandage or maybe some ammunition.  You find yourself confronted with the issue of not only your characters morality, but your own. Setting aside the fact that the game characters can get depressed, this game has a way of making YOU (the player) feel bad for what you've done. The first person I ever killed in this game made me actually stop playing just so I could absorb what happened and how I never wanted it to happen again.  I entered a run down house, it was the first occupied building I had ever looted. I quickly noticed it was inhabited and starting sneaking around, grabbing up all the items not owned by the residents. Realizing the one thing I really needed (food of course) was not among them, I decided it was time to steal. Needless to say, I got caught opening their fridge.  Running into the basement I attempt to leave without a confrontation, only to find I had never unblocked the basement exit and I was now stuck between a locked door, and a guy who wanted to kill me for stealing his food. I did the only thing I could think of and began to smash him with my crowbar. Clicking somewhat madly I didn't notice until it was to late that he was surrendering instead of fighting to the death. To late his cry reachs my ears as my final blow sends him crashing to the floor, followed shortly by his sobbing lady friend. Murderor, she cries, why did you have to kill him? Still in the heat of the moment one thought enters my twisted excuse of a human mind, 'No witnesses'. A moment later she lies next to her fallen lover as I stand over their bodies in triumph before I come to my senses.  O god, what have I done...  Determined to right the wrongs I have commited I decide to try and play as honourably as I can. Never steal from or kill civilians, avoid conflict at all cost and help out at every chance I get. That lasted until winter came...

Do i recommend? TOTALLY YES.  The atmosphere,the feelings ,the fear of getting caught while stealing,decision like ' steal medicines to an old couple? or risk fever and similar'. Every item you craft can give u an enormous benefit or penality,depending on when are you doing it. For example you can rush beds,axe,water filters to get full of resources but if a robber attacks the house and you have no weapons ,the risk of losing something valuable is high.  You'll fear and seek for new encounters at same time,wondering if they will be enemies or give you rare supplies.  just one con: there's an high chance to die at first games,and the lack of a real randomization can make all a bit repetitive.

If you enjoy survial games this game is for you   You find yourself with 3 different people each with their own skills that may help you survie the war. Each person has their own story as well and you learn more about them through the days you survie together. Along the way you may find soem other people willing to join your group but do yoiu have the food for that persojn and the rest of your group or will your group slowly starve to death. I once encounted a group of people and attacked them when they caught me stealing their food when I got back the charecter i used felt depressed and I even felt bad for doing that. This game leaves the player to choose how the group will survie by finding and trading or by being bandits by stealing and kill other people to survie the war   'F**k the war'

this game is one of the few games where you can simultaneously have the feeling of min-maxing and trying to seek value in what you do, and have your emotions going crazy. However well you do, you always feel like complete ♥♥♥♥ for something that you did at some point. Buy it if you havent, its brilliant
Loved this game, depressing but good.
One of the first games that bit me to the core with feelings. This game effected me deeply. Get it, play it, feel things.

First things first. I've never played a game that made me sit back and question if what I had done was the right thing. I have never...NEVER played a game that left me with the feeling of guilt. The war torn city of pogoren is a harsh and unforgiving climate...but when you have people counting on you to survive, will you do what is necessary?  My first play though, I managed to make it through to the end of the war (45 days) with all of my original team members (Marko, Pavle, Bruno) plus Marin, who had later joined us. The ups and downs within this game are phenomenal. The music combined with the artwork just sets such a dismal overall mood.  I remember doing things I was not proud of, but again when survival calls do you have the gall to do what is necessary? War isn't pretty, it isn't glorified. It's this. It's despair.  Take a minute and consider this... What would you do in the shoes of these people? Would you stalk, defend, and murder just to get by?   Without too many spoilers, I will leave you, the reader, with this. If you want to experience the most enlightening moments with the most loathesome ones, this will give it to you. This is the first game I've reviewed.. and I'm giving it a 9/10.. the point taken away is only because a certain part of me hates what it made me do.
Good game this, bleak but a nice antidote to your more traditional war games.

One of the best survival games I have played hands down. The game really takes you on a thrilling roller coaster of happy moments and sad ones. Can't wait to play through it again and see what this war has to offer or take away from my survivors.
War is not nice, and this game depicts how it is 'not nice' extremely well. Highly recommended for war game fans, like me.

This War of Mine is a game about your three survivors, stuck in the city after a devastating war. During the day, snipers hunt, making you stay in shelter, but at night you will scavenge for the tools you need to survive. The games events such as people who want to help, or people who want to hurt.  I am on day 17 and I have been struggling to find food and supplies. 10/10
I Had To Rob An Elderly Couple For Food  Made Me Feel Crap For Hours 10/10

I do not have words to describe, how AWESOME messages it tries to get across. It is a game unlike any other outhere.  I am into FPS and World War games, but my prespective changed a lot while playing this game.
A great game. Through touch life the characters living, it unfolds the cruelty of war. great game.

Although I do recommend this game because I enjoyed it quite a bit, I have to say it's ultimately become very disappointing. I bought This War of Mine in Early Access, expecting an unfinished game. It turned out to be fine as it was, and soon became extremely popular. And never really added anything more after that.  I'm left with a feeling that the devs reached their goal for sales/popularity and decided adding more to the game wasn't necessary, as it changed very little over the months I had it before quietly slipping from Early Access to full release.

Day 1: Simple collection of wood and materials from home. Ventured out to get some food and supplies. Looks good so far. Day 32: Running out of food. My scouter came home and beat the only woman in my party. I'm frightened. Day 33: Stole from the old couple's house. Pretty sure they're gonna die soon.  Real life: Crying myself to sleep because of what I've done. 10/10 would steal from old couple again.

If you can get this game for about 5 Bucks it´s worth playing. The gameplay feels like 'The Sims' in a warzone and isn´t really groundbreaking but it´s fun for some hours. They could have made a lot more out of the game but it ends very surprisingly after 40 ingame days just when you raised your starving characters to a self-supporting community and it actually started to be a pleasant game. What sucks is, that even when you made your community work out and there shouldnt be any problems, they start to beat up each other or create other problems for themselves. Those 'plot twists' where just annoying and seamed artificial and unnecessary. Also the music sucks. So you should listen to your own music while playing it.
The most lifechanging game. You need to play it to become a better human being.

Really love the simplicity and atmosphere of this game. the gameplay is solid and the world is unforgiving.   If you're really looking for something different, This War of Mine is probably what you're looking for

A fabulous game that everyone should play. A completely different perspective on war that no game before it dared to depict. The premise of the game is simple: Three people are trapped in an apartment during the Siege of Sarajevo and hilarity and mischief ensue. They must work together to survive the more comedic aspects of war such as pestilence, starvation, depression, and genocide.   I give this game an 8.5/10. Definitely recommended.

Really good game. You control survivors, your job is to make them survive by scavenge other house's by sending away one survivor every night while the rest of the suvivors either guard your home or sleep, but preferably a combination of both.  Absolutely worth the money.
What can I say -- this game is beautiful in its simplicity. Would highly recommend -- and would recommend higher if controller support were added!
Great game, original artwork. You really start to feel for the characters in the game!

Honestly one of the best games i've played in a while. It rewards you for playing safe but punishes you if you sometimes don't just realise that you are trying to survive in a warzone. Makes finding resources difficult as you cna't just mass stack a load of wood, components etc when scavenging and you can only ever send one person out at a time.   It seriously busts your balls if you lose your people though for example : Lost my Scavenging guy in two run throughs (haven't finished the game yet, ran out of food twice aswell) and when losing him my resources just ceased to exist.   Recommend this game massively for the atmospheric feeling of impending doom and destruction from the pestilance of life and the common bandits and other surviours in the war torn city..

Have you ever wanted to feel like a piece of crap no matter what you do? If so, this is the game for you.   Honestly, this game will give you no other option but to do the wrong thing in order to save your group, then your group members all make you feel bad for doing so.  That being said, This War of Mine takes the road that many games avoid. What happens to civilians in a warzone? It really is something different and something that is an experience in itself. It has varied gameplay with stealth, combat, scavenging, and helping others. It is up to you how you lead your group to survive until the end of the war.  Also, the DLC for the game goes to a great cause. You get content, and the money goes to help children living in warzones.  It truly is an experience that I would recommend to anyone. It shows that wars aren't simply soldiers fighting eachother, and that people have to do anything and everything to survive.
This game is wonderful!! BUT, I HOPE HAVE CHINESE VERSION IN THE FUTURE...!! BECAUSE IT CAN MAKE FULLY ENJOY THE GAME.

well, this is my first review (let me try this).. all i can say its a good game... got interesting multiple endings, its survival game you can do anything you want with the game mechanics.. and again.. its a good game.. also dont forget to buy the this war of mine charity DLC....   i will buy the DLC if i got leftovers steam wallet :>

Extremely good atmosphere! I'm really happy that I bought this game plus its 'War-Child' DLC! Can't wait to trade medicine and to look at those pieces of art :)  I recommend this game plus it's DLC! Can't wait for the 'The Little Ones' DLC!

An amazing experience, while living at war from the other side, the side of civilians just trying to stay alive and do not starve.  A very beautiful game, with great experiences. Every composition of characters is a whole new experience.  Recommended to everyone who likes a survival game.
More endurable than Shelter,to me :-( However,it reminds me of my 'dead' companions :-( Still feel so bad,due to Gyöngyhajú lány.
Amazing game and very heart moving hidden storyline.
This game so f'ing depressing.

Extremely immersive story telling about war and the effects on the survivors. There are no great choices in the struggle to live. Warning: This game will stay with you emotionally when you're not playing. Kudos to the developers and creators!
Unbelievable atmosphere. Great gameplay. A really original game. Awesome !

This is an excellent game that makes you think of war from a different perspective: that of the survivors. All the characters have had terrible senseless things happen to them. They are powerless to affect the war and struggling to survive. Resources are never plentiful and sometimes you have to make hard decisions, like whether to steal from a poor old couple or killing a civilian who attacks you first. You can't just choose to go full evil on a rampage; your characters are just normal people trying to survive and too much murder and stealing makes them lose hope and become depressed.  9/10 + Tough learning curve + Great atmospheric art + Great characters, excellent backstory - If you carefully manage resources, you might not have much to do for the last 2 weeks or so once everything's built
This Game is awsome. Great story and play through value.
very fun and yet hard i would recommend this to anyone

Honestly; This game is the best depression simulator ever! Even if you don't have depression, play 30 minutes of this, and you will! This game is incredibly good, but seriously, it will grab you by your heart strings and make you it's ♥♥♥♥♥. I've only played 6 hours because I can't play anymore without having my day ruined.

This game is amazing. A great game. Extremely depressing and emotionally disturbing. It's like a tiny window into the hellish life created by modern war.  Working through those things through the game is very fun.  It says right now 6h on record. What it really is though is more like 2. I had to keep taking a break from the game. Pausing it, going and thinking about what is happening in the game, coming back for a day or two (ingame), repeat.....  Very fun game, very disturbing game, very fun game...made my heart ache...in a good way I think.

This game is awesome as =*=*= I have bought the war child dlc wich makes me feel awesome! But what i love about this game is the vibe, when you scavenge the music makes you feel like your in a real war and are in real real danger. I would love this game on my phone but i cant afford it on android.
One of the best games I have played in my life!
Love this game. Also on android. C:

Normally I don't review games, but 'This War of Mine' is an absolutely extraordinary game!!! It reminded me of the effects games had on me years ago, with adrenaline pumping throughout my body. This game was probably one of the best buys I have done all year.  I really hope you guys enjoy it and support the developers so that it can become even greater than now!

Despite the fact that Marko was a whining piece of ♥♥♥♥ who was constantly broken while his two friends were either severly or lethally wounded for over a week, I still somehow managed to survive the war and have fun doing it.

There is little to say about this game that hasn't already been said better. Suffice it to say, the game is hard, depressing and brutal; however, it helps provide a corrective to the games that tell us war is AWESOME. Sure, those games can be great escapism (like action movies), but this game is your serious, gritty film that makes you think. It's like playing Children of Men.  Definitely one of the best games of 2014.

Unique game with unique gameplay, properly scaling adjustable difficulty, high replayability Stunning and unique artstyle combined with fitting ambient and musical assets make for a gripping atmosphere The game is still getting updated (1 year since the release) The only DLC they have gives the money (the company's share) away to charity Honest, fair and affordable pricing. While it's not technically an AAA title, it's one of the very-very rare titles that do deserve the 10/10, truly outstanding The pricing, content, quality and art style combined makes this game truly remarable and -I think- reminds everyone that even in today's greedy&quantity-over-quality industry there are still devs out there worth supporting.

So I've only played this game for a short timr, my first run through. Fairly unsuccesful, I guess, but lots to learn.  What to say about it? Intense! This game is amazingly intense and mindbending. I can imagine that some people who play it could be incredibly affected by it.   Certainly one of the most unique games I've played in a long time. I'm a fan generally of point and click, platform style puzzle games, but even that doesn't really sum up what's going on here. It's not so much puzzle solving as problem solving - amazingly real world solutions to genuinely real world dilemmas. Rather than treating it like a computer game, you genuinely need to think about each issue as it arises as if you were facing it in real life. Any concessions you make for it just being a game will see you face some pretty horrific consequences.  I can see myself racking up many, many more hours on this.

*** SPOILERS ***  What a game. 7,5/10  Replayability: 6/10 (once you know the end it kinda ruins the magic, but you can replay for better results)  + Atmosphere + Feels + Story + Gameplay + Unforgiving if you don't think your actions through  - Too short - Not enough different events - The world feels too small - Repetitive (lowish replayability) - No XP system for the survivalists   After starting over for a few times to get the game mechanics my cook dies one day before the end of the war because I got greedy for stuff, not knowing the war was ending, and tried to kill a thug who spotted me first.  War never changes, but let's hope there will be a sequel with some added features.

Side scrolling survival with a strong focus on the impact of war on a civilian population, expect difficult decisions and some degree of reflection after your first couple of play throughs. Art style and sound are both excellent and it's refreshing to play a game as a victim rather than protagonist. Recommended at the price, however please bear in mind the difficulty curve is steep at first but will largely be overcome by your fourth/fifth playthrough.

Very well balanced, although the game gets easier after the first playthrough when you know what to do.  During my second playthrough I didn't expect to get so upset once the war was over, but 2 of my characters died and it somehow managed to to give me that frog in the back of my throat...again. I wouldn't say this game was as emotional as something like Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy 6 (Final Fantasy 3 on SNES), but it does a really good job.  I will say the game lacks a bit of content near the endgame. I think the final days should be an ultimate struggle, making the end that much more emotional, like on my first playthrough.

I have just witnessed something I have never felt for awhile.... Sadness....  When I started the game, I had three survivors, Palve, Marko, and Bruno, Bruno and Marko were close friends when the bombings start and they picked up Palve along the ride. I made 2 bed in the basement and a stove in the kitchen and everything seemed to go their way, good food, medicene, everything, however, this was only during the day, at night, I sent Palve to a Ruined Villia and was shanked 3 times from the owner and had major wounds when he came back. Then everything derailed from there, looters kept on coming to loot there little safehouse and injured Marko and Bruno.  After 5 or so days, Palve died from his wounds and Marko and Bruno were the only ones alive and they kept on going, no matter what. before The Outbreak of Crime, they allowed another war victim to join them a woman named Arica. Her shelter was bombed and needed to find a new home. Marko and Bruno were heavily wounded and yet they allowed her to stay with them.  One day, as Marko and Bruno's condition grew worse and worse, Erica decided to go to the hospital to get something to help them at night, turns out that they don't sell bandages, but they have many doctors that could heal the two friends. As Arica arrived back to the house....... It was all lost.....  The two beds held the bodies of not friends nor enemies..... But the remains of what left Arica......  10/10 would go through this emotional rollercoaster again
